Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref>), all meaning "breast-band", a band of wool or linen that was wrapped across the breasts and tied or pinned at the back.<ref>{{cite book|title=Le Corset a Travers Les Ages (1893) |language=French |publisher= Kessinger Publishing |first1= Ernest |last1=Leoty |first2=Saint Elme |last2=Gautier |isbn=1-167-74666-X |pages=120 |date=10 September 2010}} Reprint of the 1893 edition</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=ME18871111.1.2&e=-------10--1----0-all |title=The Figure and Corsets. Mataura Ensign (New Zealand) November 11, 1887 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151103190025/http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=ME18871111.1.2&e=-------10--1----0-all |archivedate=3 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:7333 - Piraeus Arch. Museum, Athens - Artemis - Photo by Giovanni Dall'Orto, Nov 14 2009.jpg|thumb|left|y-shaped breast bands on a bronze statue of [[Artemis]], goddess of the hunt (mid-4th century BC). These bands form an archery harness, which a quiver of arrows attaches to.]] A belt could also be fastened over a simple tunic-like garment or undergarment, just below the breasts or over the breasts. When the ''apodesmos'' was worn under the breasts, it accentuated them. Another word for a breast-band or belt was ''strophion'' (Gr: στρόφιον).<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dstro%2Ffion στρόφιον] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118092825/http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dstro%2Ffion |date=18 January 2016 }}, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Ewing, Elizabeth |title=Underwear: A History |location=New York |publisher=Theatre Arts |year=1972}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.open.ac.uk/Arts/classtud/cbaw/stafford.htm |first=Emma |last=Stafford, University of Leeds |title=The Clothed Body in the Ancient World 17–19 January 2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041209165542/http://www.open.ac.uk/Arts/classtud/cbaw/stafford.htm |archivedate=9 December 2004 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A further term was ''kestós'' (Gr: κεστός, Latin: ''cestus''), used specifically for [[Aphrodite]]'s charmed [[Girdle#History|girdle]] in the [[Iliad]],<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dkesto%2Fs κεστός] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161007114101/http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dkesto%2Fs |date=7 October 2016 }}, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref> whose power was to make every woman who wore it irresistible to men. In view of its association with the love goddess, this type of garment probably had an erotic connotation because of its effect to accentuate the breast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dollhousebettie.com/index.php?option=com_myblog&Itemid=0&lang=en&show=454|title=Partial Coverage - History of Lingerie II: Ancient Greeks|first=|last=2958|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115071343/http://www.dollhousebettie.com/index.php?option=com_myblog&Itemid=0&lang=en&show=454|archivedate=15 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kbender.blogspot.de/2013/01/the-girdle-of-aphrodite-venusor-was-it.html|title=Iconography in Art History: The girdle of Aphrodite-Venus...or was it her 'wonderbra'?|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629021226/http://kbender.blogspot.de/2013/01/the-girdle-of-aphrodite-venusor-was-it.html|archivedate=29 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The basic item of classical Greek costume was the ''[[peplos]]'', later the ''[[Chiton (costume)|chiton]]'' (two rectangular pieces of cloth partially sewn together on both sides, with a {{convert|12|to|15|in|cm|order=flip}} overfold or ''apoptygma''), which evolved into the [[chemise]], the most common item of underclothing worn by men and women for hundreds of years (also variously known as a smock or shift). In Sparta, women usually wore the chiton completely open on the left side.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
===Rome=== [[File:Pompeii Fresco Brassiere.jpg|thumb|Breast band on an otherwise nude woman (detail from a wall painting at [[Pompeii]], 62–79 AD)]] [[Women in ancient Rome]] adopted a form of the Greek ''apodesme'', known as the ''strophium'' or ''mamillare''. Since the Romans regarded large breasts as comical, or characteristic of aging or unattractive women,<ref>[[Martial]], ''Epigrams'' 1.100, 2.52, 14.66; Amy Richlin, ''The Garden of Priapus: Sexuality and Aggression in Roman Humor'' (Oxford University Press, 1983, 1992), pp. 52, 54, 68, 110; Kelly Olson, "The Appearance of the Young Roman Girl," in ''Roman Dress and the Fabrics of Roman Culture'' (University of Toronto Press, 2008), p. 143; John R. Clarke, ''Looking at Lovemaking: Constructions of Sexuality in Roman Art 100 B.C.–A.D. 250'' (University of California Press, 1998, 2001), p. 34.</ref> young girls wore breast bands ''(fascia)'' secured tightly in the belief that doing so would prevent overly large, sagging breasts.<ref>Olson, "The Appearance of the Young Roman Girl," p. 143.</ref>
[[File:Hoxne Hoard body chain.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The gold body chain from the [[Hoxne hoard]] resembles a jeweled version of the crossed breast band]] The so-called "bikini girls" [[Roman mosaic|mosaic]] from the [[Villa Romana del Casale]] (4th century AD) shows women performing gymnastic or dance routines while wearing a garment similar to a strapless bra and briefs.<ref>H. Lee, "Athletics and the Bikini Girls from Piazza Armerina," ''Stadion'' 10 (1984) 45–75; M. Torelli, "Piazza Armerina: Note di iconologia", in ''La Villa romana del Casale di Piazza Armerina,'' edited by G. Rizza (Catania, 1988), p. 152; Katherine M.D. Dunbabin, ''Mosaics of the Greek and Roman World'' (Cambridge University Press, 1999), p. 133.</ref><ref name=vroma>{{cite web|url=http://www.vroma.org/~bmcmanus/clothing.html|title=Roman Clothing|last=McManus|first=Barbara F.|date=August 2003|publisher=The College of New Rochelle|accessdate=7 May 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JHldQF7z?url=http://www.vroma.org/~bmcmanus/clothing.html|archivedate=31 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Other primitive iterations of a bra are depicted earlier in wall paintings preserved at [[Pompeii]] by the [[eruption of Vesuvius]] in 79 AD.<ref name="Dierichs 1993">{{cite book |first=Angelika |last=Dierichs |title=Erotik in der Römischen Kunst |language=German|location= Zabern, Mainz |year=1993 |publisher=Zaberns Bildbände zur Archäologie |isbn= 3-8053-1540-6}}</ref>
Sometimes in the most sexually explicit Roman paintings, [[Sexuality in ancient Rome#Breasts|the breasts]] are kept covered by the ''strophium''. The settings in which the paintings are found indicate that the women depicted may be [[prostitution in ancient Rome|prostitutes]].<ref>Clarke, ''Looking at Lovemaking,'' p. 73 ''et passim''; John G. Younger, ''Sex in the Ancient World from A to Z'' (Routledge, 2005), p. 35.</ref>
===East Asia=== {{main|dudou|yếm}} In [[China]], a loose [[silk]] bodice tied at the waist and tied or looped around the neck called the [[dudou]] (<small>lit.</small> "belly cover") came into fashion among wealthy women during the [[Ming dynasty]] of the 14th–17th centuries.<ref>{{citation |editor-first=Partho |editor-last=Shanner |display-editors=0 |title=Oriental Clothing and Modern Fetishism |location=Hong Kong |publisher=Yeti |date=1996 }}.</ref> It remained popular under the succeeding [[Qing dynasty]] (17th–20th centuries).<ref>{{citation |contribution-url=http://app1.chinadaily.com.cn/star/history/00-06-20/l06-dudou.html |contribution=Do You Dare to Wear a Dudou? |last=Xu |first=Xiaomin |authormask=Xu Xiaomin |date=20 June 2000 |title=Shanghai Star}}.</ref><ref>{{citation |contribution-url=http://www.chinese-fashion.com/dudou.html |contribution=History of Dudou |title=Chinese Fashion }}.</ref><ref>{{citation |contribution-url=http://app1.chinadaily.com.cn/star/2003/1030/cu18-1.html |contribution=Keeping Abreast of Change |title=Shanghai Star }}.</ref> It was adopted into [[Vietnamese clothing|Vietnamese culture]] as the ''[[yếm]]'' and remains in traditional use among the two cultures.
==Middle Ages== In Europe, in the [[Middle Ages]] it was exceptional for women to restrict or support their breasts and if they did, they probably used something like a cloth binder, as is suggested in descriptions of the time{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}. A widely quoted statement is that an edict of [[Strasbourg]] in the [[Holy Roman Empire]], dated 1370 states, "No woman will support the bust by the disposition of a blouse or by tightened dress."{{dubious|date=September 2015}}{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}} An archeological find circa 1390 to 1485 revealed that women did in fact support their breasts in the Middle Ages. Four lace-decorated bras were found among 3,000 textile fragments during a renovation project in an Austrian castle.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lobell|first1=Jamrett|title=Medieval Fashion Statement|journal=Archaeology|date=Nov–Dec 2012|volume=65|issue=6|page=12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/600-year-old-linen-bras-found-in-austrian-castle/|title=600 year old linen bras found in Austrian castle|year=2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220141104/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/600-year-old-linen-bras-found-in-austrian-castle/|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> By the time of [[Charles VII of France]] (1403–1461), a gauze drape was used over the bust.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}
Generally, in the Middle Ages the breasts were minimized in dresses with straight bodices, full skirts and high necklines, designed primarily for function rather than emphasis on form. Late medieval dresses are fitted precisely and snugly to the body and function as breast support. Depictions of women in 14th- and 15th-century art show a high, rounded breast silhouette on women old and young, full-busted and small. This look is not possible without support. The 15th-century ideal form was small-breasted and full-figured, symbolizing abundance of fertility.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
By the time of the [[Renaissance]], [[décolletage]] became very fashionable. There was some status to firm breasts in upper class women, who did not [[breast feed]]. Infants were given to [[wet nurse]]s to breast feed, since nursing was considered bad if a woman wanted to maintain an ideal form.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}} Among the wealthier classes, the corset was beginning to appear by the mid-15th century.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}}
[[Catherine de' Medici]] (1519–1589, wife of King [[Henry II of France]]) is widely, and wrongly, blamed for the corset. She was reported to have prohibited wide waists at court in the 1550s, legend suggesting she made them wear steel framework corsets.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}
Elaborate constraints placed on women's figures over the years were not universal. Corsetry made it virtually impossible to work, so simpler functional garments were worn by women who worked inside or outside the home. Support for the breasts was often provided by a simple tie under the breast line, in the bodice.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}
==Renaissance== [[File:Lippo lippi woman.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Painting illustrating Renaissance ideals.]]
Early corsets of the 16th century consisted of paste-stiffened linen and a primitive [[busk]] at the front but later included iron supports at the side and back. The emphasis now was on form, with compression of the breasts forcing them upwards to the point of almost spilling out, so a considerable part of the breast was exposed. The ideal form was a flat torso, which inevitably pushed the breasts upwards and out. The labouring class by contrast wore a simple front-lacing [[cotte]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
During the [[French Revolution]] and the [[Napoleonic Wars]], any garment associated with the aristocracy was frowned upon, including those with visible décolletage. The breasts were often supported by a tie below the bust, and extant bust-support garments ranged from soft stays to wrap-front items similar to sports bras. In 1814, the court and the corset returned.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}
[[File:Coronet Corset Co.gif|180px|thumb|right|Victorian silhouette contrasted with the new Edwardian "S-bend" silhouette]] [[File:CorsetLeonJulesRAINAL Freres13b.png|thumb|180px|right|A therapeutic elastic breast girdle for 'breast hypertrophy', Catalogue of Leon Jules Rainal Freres 1907]] [[File:LeNouveauSoutienGorge1906.png|180px|thumb|right|New bra 1906]] [[File:1881-empire-bra-vie-parisienne-henri-montaut.gif|180px|right|thumb|One of the earliest depictions of something closely resembling a modern bra, an 1881 illustration which claims to show an [[1795–1820 in fashion|early-19th-century]] garment]]
===French Empire=== {{Main|1795–1820 in fashion}} [[Empire silhouette|Empire]] fashion originated during the [[Directoire style|Directoire]] period, popularized by women such as [[Joséphine de Beauharnais]]. "Inspired by the mania for the Graeco-Roman, with its connotations of artistic excellence and political liberty, fashionable women discarded corsets and adopted sleeveless transparent tunics.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stuart|first1=Andrea|title=The rose of Martinique : a life of Napoleon's Josephine|date=2003|publisher=Macmillan|location=London|isbn=978-0333739334|page=163}}</ref> Embracing the classical silhouette, in [[Great Britain|Britain]] this period was known as the [[1795–1820 in fashion|Regency]]. During this era, "fashion-conscious women ... pored over fashion journals like ''Le Journal des Dames et de la Mode'', the era's version of [[Vogue (magazine)|''Vogue'']], in order to see what Josephine was wearing and attempt to copy her style.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stuart|first1=Andrea|title=The rose of Martinique : a life of Napoleon's Josephine|date=2003|publisher=Macmillan|location=London|isbn=978-0333739334|page=335}}</ref> The most popular chest support in this period were short stays, a type of lightly boned corset.
===Victorian era in Britain=== In the [[Victorian era]], despite contemporary ideas about morality, women's clothing was paradoxically designed to emphasize both the breasts and hips by [[tightlacing]] the waist. Victorian women were encumbered with many layers of clothing, including a [[chemise]] with a drawstring neckline, usually [[Undergarment|drawers]], then the corset and corset cover, the under [[petticoat]], the hoop skirt, the over petticoat, and finally the dress. According to the social expectations of the times, even the lowest-cut evening gown should dip no lower than three finger breadths below the clavicles.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}
===Edwardian era in Britain===
By the [[Edwardian period|Edwardian era]], with some increase in women's physical activities, the corset started to retreat southward again, becoming more like a girdle and accompanied by the appearance of a separate upper garment, the ''Bust Bodice'', or BB. For those who instead wore a one-piece undershift (''unionsuit''), this separated into the camisole and drawers. These were not designed for support but merely coverage.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}
Women's dress emphasized an "S" shape, with an indrawn stomach giving prominence to the posterior and bust. In the late 19th century and early 20th century the bosom could still be displayed. "The high-water mark of modesty would ebb after sunset some six inches!"<ref>Cunnington C.W. A Handbook of English Costume in the 19th century</ref> Corsets remained the main form of support, but war and its impact on lifestyle and materials meant that its future was uncertain.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
==The Clothing Reform Movement== {{Anchor|The Clothing Reform Movement}} {{Main|Victorian dress reform}} The evolution of the bra from the corset was driven by two parallel movements: health professionals' concerns about the cruel, constraining effects of the corset, and the clothing reform movement of feminists who saw that greater participation of women in society would require emancipation from corsetry. Prominent amongst these were the Rational Dress Society,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~UG02/hendrick/women.html |title=The Possibility of Mobility |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329041457/http://xroads.virginia.edu/~UG02/hendrick/women.html |archivedate=29 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> the National Dress Reform Association,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.galenahistorymuseum.org/bloomergirls.htm |author=Nancy Wolfe |title=The Bloomer Girls: America's Dress Reform Movement of the 1850s|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214202826/http://www.galenahistorymuseum.org/bloomergirls.htm |archivedate=14 December 2006 }}</ref> and the Reform Dress Association.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.rochester.edu/index.cfm?page=1800|title=Upstate New York and the Women's Rights Movement|accessdate=13 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521191026/https://www.lib.rochester.edu/index.cfm?PAGE=1800|archivedate=21 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Although there were a number of voices warning about the considerable health risks of corsets, health professions were generally muted, and women ignored "unfashionable" advice. The health professions concentrated more on psychosomatic complaints, which were in fact probably related to corsetry. Ill health was considered synonymous with femininity, and a pale and sickly demeanor was normative. (Fictional heroines often died from tuberculosis, or "consumption." This made them pale and kept them immobile.) Corsets were supposed to provide both physical and moral support.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
Some physicians ignored colleagues who felt corsets were a medical necessity because of women's biology and the needs of civilized order. The physicians who raised the alarm pointed to nausea, bowel disturbances, eating disorders, breathlessness, flushing, fainting, and gynecological problems. [[Bed rest]] was a common prescription for the "weaker sex," which of course implied relief from corsetry.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
Women's interest in sport, particularly bicycling, forced a rethinking, and women's groups called for "emancipation garments." [[Elizabeth Stuart Phelps]] urged women to "burn the [[corsets]]!" in 1874.{{Citation needed|date=April 2012}} Indirectly and directly, sports empowered women in other social climates.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
Not surprisingly, corsetieres fought back, embellishing their products to be frilly and feminine in the 1870s. Advertising took on overtones of erotic imagery, even if in practice they acted as a deterrent to sexuality, especially when they started appearing in men's magazines, stressing [[cleavage (breasts)|cleavage]] and bare arms (then taboo). Dolls assumed the corseted image, implanting an image of the "ideal" female form. Corsets certainly reinforced the image of a weaker sex, unable to defend themselves, and also made it a challenge to disrobe.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
In practice, early bras made little market penetration. They were expensive, and only educated wealthy reformers wore them to any extent.<ref name="uplift"/>
American women who made important contributions included [[Amelia Bloomer]] (1818–1894) ("When you find a burden in belief or apparel, cast it off")<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fashion-era.com/rational_dress.htm#Amelia%20Bloomer%201818-1894 |author=Pauline Thomas |title=Fashion Era: Rational dress reform |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115045046/http://www.fashion-era.com/rational_dress.htm#Amelia%20Bloomer%201818-1894 |archivedate=15 November 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and Dr. [[Mary Edwards Walker]] (1832–1919).
===The emergence of the bra in the 19th century===
There are considerable differences of opinion as to who "invented" the modern brassière or bra. Patent dates indicate some of the landmark developments; a large number of patents for bra-like devices were granted in the 19th century. However, what is regarded as the world's oldest push-up bra was discovered in storage at the Science Museum in London. Designed to enhance cleavage, the bra is said to be from the early 19th century.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/2944282/Worlds-oldest-Wonderbra-found.html?OTC-RSS&ATTR=News |title=World's oldest Wonderbra found |location=London |work=The Sun |first=Kate |last=Wighton |date=22 April 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023061436/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/2944282/Worlds-oldest-Wonderbra-found.html?OTC-RSS&ATTR=News |archivedate=23 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A bra-like device<ref>{{Cite patent|US|24033}}</ref> that gave a ''symmetrical rotundity'' to the wearer's breasts was patented in 1859 by [[Henry S. Lesher]] of Brooklyn, New York. In 1863, a "corset substitute" was patented by Luman L. Chapman of Camden, New Jersey. Historians refer to it as a "proto-bra."<ref name="uplift"/>
In 1876, dressmaker Olivia Flynt was granted four patents covering the "true Corset" or "Flynt Waist." It was aimed at the larger-breasted woman. Reformers stimulated demand for and probably purchased these early garments on "hygienic" grounds because of their concerns about the corset. Initially Flynt's garments were only available by mail order, but they eventually appeared in department and clothing stores and catalogues. Her designs won a bronze medal at the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanics Association in 1878, at the Cotton Centennial Exposition in Atlanta in 1884–5, and at the Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893.<ref name="stanley">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uRJt7QqA7GEC&dq=Mothers+and+Daughters+of+Invention:+Notes+for+a+Revised+History+of+Technology&source=gbs_navlinks_s |last=Stanley |first=Autumn |title=Mothers and Daughters of Invention: Notes for a Revised History of Technology |publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=1993 |accessdate=24 January 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627003513/http://books.google.com/books?id=uRJt7QqA7GEC&dq=Mothers+and+Daughters+of+Invention:+Notes+for+a+Revised+History+of+Technology&source=gbs_navlinks_s |archivedate=27 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>{{rp|171}}
According to ''[[Life magazine|Life]]'' magazine, in 1889 [[Herminie Cadolle]] of France invented the first modern bra.<ref>Pechter E. A new method for determining bra size and predicting post-augmentation breast size. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery 102 (4) September 1998, 1259–1265</ref> It appeared in a corset catalogue as a two-piece undergarment, which she originally called the ''corselet gorge'', and later ''le bien-être'' (or "the well-being"). Her garment effectively cut the traditional corset in two: The lower part was a corset for the waist and the upper part supported the breasts with shoulder straps. Her description reads "designed to sustain the bosom and supported by the shoulders." She patented her invention and showed it at the Great Exhibition of 1889. The company, still family-owned, claims today that Herminie "freed women by inventing the first Bra."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cadolle.com/fr/histoire|title=House of Cadolle, Histoire|language=fr|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204170542/http://cadolle.com/fr/histoire|archivedate=4 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> By 1905, the upper half was sold separately as a ''soutien-gorge'', the name by which bras are still known in France. She also introduced the use of "rubber thread" or [[Elastomer|elastic]].
In 1893, Marie Tucek received a U.S. patent<ref>{{Cite patent|US|494397}}</ref> for a device that consisted of separate pockets for each breast above a metal supporting plate and shoulder straps fastened by hook-and-eye. This invention more closely resembled the modern bra known today, and was a precursor to the [[underwire bra]].<ref>{{US patent reference | number = 494397 | y = 1893| m = 03| d = 28| inventor = Marie Tucek| title = Breast Supporter}}</ref><ref name="Tucek">{{cite news| last = Riordan| first = Teresa| title = Patents; In bra technology, an incremental improvement can translate into comfort.| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/28/business/patents-in-bra-technology-an-incremental-improvement-can-translate-into-comfort.html?sec=technology&spon=&pagewanted=all| accessdate = 13 June 2017| date = 28 October 2002| work = The New York Times| quote = Professor Farrell-Beck said the antecedents for underwire in bras date to at least 1893, when Marie Tucek of New York City patented a ''breast supporter'', a sort of early push-up bra made of either metal or cardboard and then covered with fabric.| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5gHMwNkFs?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/28/business/patents-in-bra-technology-an-incremental-improvement-can-translate-into-comfort.html?sec=technology&spon=&pagewanted=all| archivedate = 24 April 2009| df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Home-sewn garments competed with factory-made, ready-to-wear garments. The bra was at first an alternative to the corset, as a [[negligée]] or at-home wear, or worn by women with medical issues stemming from corsets. After the [[History of corsets|straight-fronted corset]] became fashionable in the early 20th century, a bra or "bust supporter" became a necessity for full-busted women because the straight-fronted corset did not offer as much support and containment as the Victorian styles. Early bras were either wrap-around [[bodice]]s or boned, close-fitting [[camisole]]s (both worn over the corset). They were designed to hold the bust in and down against the corset, which provided upward support.
Advertising of the times, typically in periodicals, stressed the advantages of bras in health and comfort over corsets and portrayed garments with shoulder supports in a mono-bosom style and with limited adaptability. Their major appeal was to those for whom lung function and mobility were priorities, rather than outer appearance.<ref name="uplift"/>
==The 20th century and modern era bra (United States)==
[[File:Jacob-brassiere-patent-1914-landscape.png|thumb|upright|Jacob's [[brassiere]], from the original [[patent application]].]] [[File:JacobPatent1914pg2.jpg|thumb|upright|Jacob's [[brassiere]], from the original [[patent application]].]] [[File:USpatent1156808.gif|right|thumb|upright|1913 Bust reducing bra US Patent 1156808.]]
The first modern bra was patented by the German Christine Hardt in 1889.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Sigmund Lindauer from Stuttgart-Bad Cannstatt, Germany developed a bra for mass production in 1912 and patented it in 1913. It was mass-produced by Mechanischen Trikotweberei Ludwig Maier und Cie. in Böblingen, Germany.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} With metal shortages, World War I encouraged the end of the corset. By the time the war ended, most fashion-conscious women in Europe and North America were wearing bras. From there the bra was adopted by women in Asia, Africa, and Latin America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://angelasancartier.net/brassiere|title=Brassiere - Clothing and Fashion|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129043157/http://angelasancartier.net/brassiere|archivedate=29 November 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 1910, Mary Phelps Jacob (known later in life as [[Caresse Crosby]]), a 19-year-old New York socialite, purchased a sheer evening gown for a debutante ball. At that time, the only acceptable undergarment was a [[corset]] stiffened with whalebone. Mary had large breasts and found that the whalebone visibly poked out around her plunging neckline and from under the sheer fabric. Dissatisfied with this arrangement, she worked with her maid to fashion two silk handkerchiefs together with some pink ribbon and cord.<ref name="hamalian">{{cite book |last=Hamalian |first=Linda |title=The Cramoisy Queen: A Life of Caresse Crosby |publisher=Southern Illinois University|year=2005|isbn=0-8093-1865-2}}</ref>{{rp|7}} <ref name=lost>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=tJPWAAAAMAAJ|title= Lost generation journal, Volumes 6–10|publisher= Literary Enterprises Inc.|year= 1979|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140626224444/http://books.google.com/books?id=tJPWAAAAMAAJ|archivedate= 26 June 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Her innovation drew immediate attention that evening and, at the request of family and friends, she made more of her new device. When she received a request for one from a stranger, who offered a dollar for her efforts, she realized that her device could turn into a viable business.<ref name="hamalian"/>{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
On November 3, 1914, the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent Office]] issued the first U.S. patent<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZXWrkV9A_KoC&pg=PA111 |title=Sports Science Handbook: A-H |first=Simon P. R. |last=Jenkins |page=400 pages |publisher=Multi-Science Publishing Co. Ltd. |edition=first |date=1 July 2005 |isbn=978-0-906522-36-3 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512214624/http://books.google.com/books?id=ZXWrkV9A_KoC&pg=PA111 |archivedate=12 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{US patent reference | number = 1115674 | y = 1914 | m = November | d = 3 | inventor = Mary Phelps Jacob | title = Backless Brassiere}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Breastfeeding |first=Anne P. |last=Mark |date=15 November 2000 |accessdate=20 January 2011 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s5RSGLuMnnEC&pg=PA54 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116233016/https://books.google.com/books?id=s5RSGLuMnnEC&pg=PA54 |archivedate=16 November 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>{{rp|54}} for the "Backless Bra." Crosby's patent was for a device that was lightweight, soft, comfortable to wear, and naturally separated the breasts, unlike the corset, which was heavy, stiff, uncomfortable, and had the effect of creating a "monobosom."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fashion-era.com/edwardian_corsetry.htm |title=Edwardian Corsetry Fashion History |first=Pauline Weston |last=Thomas |publisher=Fashion-Era.com |date=September 2004 |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828090322/http://www.fashion-era.com/edwardian_corsetry.htm |archivedate=28 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Clothing through American History, 1900 to the Present |first= Amy T. |last= Peterson |others=Valerie Hewitt, Heather Vaughan, and Ann T. Kellogg |date=30 October 2008 |pages=424 pages |publisher=Greenwood|isbn=978-0-313-33395-8}}</ref>
Crosby managed to secure a few orders from department stores, but her business never took off. Her husband [[Harry Crosby]] discouraged her from pursuing the business and persuaded her to close it.<ref name="hamalian"/>{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} She later sold the bra patent to the [[Warnaco|Warners Brothers]] Corset Company in [[Bridgeport]], [[Connecticut]], for $1,500 (roughly equivalent to ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|1500|1922}}}} in current dollars). Warner manufactured the "Crosby" bra for a while, but it did not become a popular style and eventually was discontinued.<ref name=uplift>{{cite book |title=Uplift: The Bra in America |author1=Jane Farrell-Beck |author2=Colleen Gau |location=Philadelphia |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |year=2002 |volume=xvi|pages=243|ISBN=0-8122-3643-2}}</ref> Warner went on to earn more than $15 million from the bra patent over the next 30 years.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
Bras became more common and widely promoted over the course of the 1910s, aided by the continuing trend towards lighter, shorter corsets that offered increasingly less bust support and containment. In 1917 at the beginning of the U.S. involvement in [[World War I]], the U.S. War Industries Board asked women to stop buying corsets to free up metal for war production. This was said to have saved some 28,000 tons of metal, enough to build two battleships.<ref name="rosenthal">{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/theymadeamerica/whomade/rosenthal_hi.html |title=Ida Rosenthal, Brassiere Tycoon |work=Who Made America? |date=20 December 2007 |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170618141809/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/theymadeamerica/whomade/rosenthal_hi.html |archivedate=18 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
It has been said that the bra took off the way it did in large part because of World War I, which shook up gender roles by putting many women to work in factories and uniforms for the first time. The war also influenced social attitudes toward women and helped to liberate them from corsets. But women were already moving into the retail and clerical sectors. Thus the bra emerged from something that was once discreetly tucked into the back pages of women's magazines in the 1890s, to prominent display in department stores such as Sears, Roebuck, and Montgomery Ward by 1918. Advertising was now promoting the shaping of the bust to contemporary fashion demands, and sales reflected this.<ref name ="uplift"/>{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
===The 1920s=== As the corset became shorter during the later 1910s, it provided less support to the bust. By 1920 the corset started at the waist, and bust containment yielded entirely to the bra. A low, sloping bustline became more fashionable. Brassieres from the late 1910s and early 1920s were merely slightly shaped bandeaus (bandeaux) style, holding the bust in and down by means of a clip attached to the corset.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
This culminated in the "boyish" silhouette of the [[Flapper]] era of the 1920s, with little bust definition. The term (which in the mid-1910s referred to preteen and early-teenage girls) was adopted by the [[J. Walter Thompson]] advertising agency in the 1920s for their younger adult customers. The [[androgyne|androgynous]] figure then in style downplayed women's natural curves through the use of a bandeau bra, which flattened breasts. It was relatively easy for small-busted women to conform to the flat-chested look of the Flapper era. Women with larger breasts tried products like the popular Symington Side Lacer that, when laced at the sides, pulled and helped to flatten women's chests. Yet some "bras" of the early 1920s were little more than camisoles.
In 1922, Russian immigrant [[Ida Rosenthal]] was a seamstress at the small New York City dress shop Enid Frocks. She and her husband William Rosenthal, along with shop owner Enid Bissett, changed the look of women's fashion. They noticed that a bra that fit one woman did not fit another woman with the same bra size. With $4,500 invested in their new business, they developed bras for all ages. Their innovation was designed to make their dresses look better on the wearer by increasing the shaping of the bandeau bra to enhance and support women's breasts. They named the company [[Maidenform|Maiden Form]], a deliberate contrast with the name of a competitor, "Boyishform Company."<ref name=uplift/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Smithsonian Institution, Museum of American History Archives |title=Maidenform Collection, 1922–1997 No. 585 |author1=Jennifer Snyder |author2=Mimi Minnick |date=August 1997 – July 1999 |url=http://americanhistory.si.edu/archives/d7585.htm |deadurl=yes |accessdate=24 January 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016082310/http://americanhistory.si.edu/archives/d7585.htm |archivedate=16 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> Maiden Form routed Boyishform by 1924, accenting and lifting rather than flattening the bust. In 1927, William Rosenthal, the president of [[Maidenform|Maiden Form]], filed patents for nursing, full-figured, and the first seamed uplift bra.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/maidenform-inc-history |title=Maidenform Inc. History |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706182250/http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/maidenform-inc-history/ |archivedate=6 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
These fashion changes coincided with health professionals beginning to link breast care and comfort to motherhood and lactation, and campaigned against breast flattening. The emphasis shifted from minimizing the breasts to uplifting and accenting them. Women, especially the younger set, welcomed the bra as a modern garment.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
While manufacturing was beginning to become more organized, homemade bras and bandeaux were still quite popular, usually made of white cotton, but they were little more than bust bodices with some separation. [[File:Bra.png|180px|right|thumb|upright|Drawing of a woman wearing bra, from Feb 28, 1930 United States Patent 1825579 application]]
===The 1930s=== The word "brassiere" was gradually shortened to "bra" in the 1930s. According to a 1934 survey by ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', "bra" was the most commonly used expression for the garment among college women.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} The bra was becoming more sophisticated, and home-sewn versions vanished in the 1930s. In October 1932, the S.H. Camp and Company correlated the size and pendulousness of a woman's breasts to letters of the alphabet, A through D. Camp's advertising featured letter-labeled profiles of breasts in the February 1933 issue of ''Corset and Underwear Review''. In 1937, Warner began to feature cup sizing in its products. Two other companies, Model and Fay-Miss, began to offer A, B, C and D cups in the late 1930s. Catalog companies continued to use the designations Small, Medium and Large through the 1940s.<ref name=uplift/><ref>{{cite book |title=The Lingerie Handbook |first=Rebecca |last=Apsan |others=Sarah Stark |pages=186 |publisher=Workman Publishing Company |date=20 October 2006 |isbn=0-7611-4323-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KBobur5ZgX0C&pg=PA30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512203239/http://books.google.com/books?id=KBobur5ZgX0C&pg=PA30 |archivedate=12 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=steele/>{{rp|101}} Adjustable bands were introduced using multiple eye and hook positions in the 1930s.
As with other women's products, consumer adoption was encouraged by successful advertising and [[marketing]] campaigns. Saleswomen played a key role, helping clients find the right garment, as did the changing role of women in [[society]]. Much of this [[marketing]] was aimed at young women.
Bras rapidly became a major industry over the 1930s, with improvements in fiber technology, fabrics, colours, patterns, and options, and did much better than the retail industry in general. Innovations included Warners' use of elastic, the adjustable strap, the sized cup, and padded bras for smaller-breasted women. In the US production moved outside of New York and Chicago, and advertising started to exploit [[Hollywood glamour]] and become more specialised. Department stores developed fitting areas, and customers, stores and manufacturers all benefited. Manufacturers even arranged fitting training courses for saleswomen. International sales started to form an increasing part of the U.S. bra manufacturer's market. Prices started to make bras available to a wider market, and home-made competition dwindled. Other major manufacturers of the 1930s included Triumph, Maidenform, Gossard, ([[Courtaulds]]), [[Spirella]], Spencer, Twilfit, and Symington.
The culturally preferred silhouette among Western women during the 1930s was a pointy bust, which further increased demand for a forming garment. [[File:Bra2.png|180px|right|thumb|Drawing of a woman wearing bra, from 1947 United States patent application]]
===The 1940s=== [[File:Safety garb for women workers. The uniform at the left, complete with the plastic "bra" on the right, will prevent... - NARA - 522882.jpg|thumb|Two women show off a new uniform - including a plastic 'bra' - designed to help prevent occupational accidents among female war workers in Los Angeles in 1943.]]The Second World War had a major impact on clothing. In the United States, military women were enlisted for the first time in the lower ranks and were fitted with uniform underwear. Willson Goggles, a Pennsylvania firm that manufactured safety equipment for manual workers, is believed to have introduced the plastic "SAF-T-BRA", designed to protect women on the factory floor.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mcdermott|first=Kerry|title=The armoured bra! Women at war photos reveal the lengths women went to take men’s industrial roles during WW2|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2316409/Showing-support-war-effort-The-plastic-bra-designed-protect-women-took-mens-industrial-roles-World-War-Two.html|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=Mail Online|date=April 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130707023450/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2316409/Showing-support-war-effort-The-plastic-bra-designed-protect-women-took-mens-industrial-roles-World-War-Two.html|archivedate=7 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Advertising appealed to both patriotism and the concept that bras and [[girdles]] were somehow "protection". Dress codes appeared{{spaced ndash}}for example, [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] informed their workers that bras must be worn because of "good taste, anatomical support, and morale".
[[Military terminology]] crept into product marketing, as represented by the highly structured, conically pointed [[List of brassiere designs|Torpedo or Bullet bra]], designed for "maximum projection". The bullet bra was worn by the [[Sweater Girl]], a busty and wholesome "girl next door" whose tight-fitting outergarments accentuated her artificially enhanced [[curve]]s. Underwire began to be used in bra construction. Actresses like [[Jane Russell]] appeared in photographs wearing the new bras that emphasized the "lift and separate" design, which influenced later bra design.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} For the movie, ''The Outlaw'', which features actress Jane Russell, the producer and airplane designer Howard Hughes constructed the Cantilever bra for Russell to wear in the movie.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Apsan|first1=Rebecca|title=The Lingerie Handbook: Transform Your Body, Transform Yourself|date=2006|publisher=Workman Publishing|location=New York}}</ref> Hughes constructed the bra so that it would fit and support Jane Russell's breasts. Hughes created the bra on the basis of bridge building. After seeing Jane Russell and her bust in the movie, women sought to recreate the look on their own chests.
The war presented unique challenges for industry. Women's occupations shifted dramatically, with far more employed outside the home and in industry. Severe material shortages limited design choices. Advertising, promotion, and consumerism were limited but started to appear directed at minorities (e.g., ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'' in 1945) and teens. Many manufacturers only survived by making tents and parachutes in addition to bras. American industry was now freed from European influences, particularly French, and it became more distinctive. Again there was concern about the use of badly needed steel in corsets and the British Government carried out a survey of women's usage of underwear in 1941. This showed that "on average, women owned 1.2 bras (housewives 0.8 and agricultural workers 1.9)". <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/mro/news-release/seventy-years-of-social-surveys/socsurv02092011-nr.html|title=[ARCHIVED CONTENT] UK Government Web Archive – The National Archives|first=Internet Memory|last=Foundation|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527144811/http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/mro/news-release/seventy-years-of-social-surveys/socsurv02092011-nr.html|archivedate=27 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===The 1950s===
[[File:Patti Page 1955.JPG|thumb|[[Patti Page]] wearing a bullet bra in 1955.]] Following the Second World War, material availability, production and marketing, and demand for a greater variety of consumer goods, including bras. The [[baby boom]] specifically created a demand for maternity and [[nursing bra]]s, and television provided new promotional opportunities. Manufacturers responded with new fabrics, colours, patterns, styles, padding and elasticity. Hollywood fashion and glamour influenced women's fashion choices including bras like the cone-shaped, spiral-stitched [[List of brassiere designs|bullet bra]] popularized by actresses like [[Patti Page]], [[Marilyn Monroe]], and [[Lana Turner]], who was nicknamed the "[[Sweater Girl]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Lingerie from History We Would (Probably) Never Wear Again|url=http://www.nowthatslingerie.com/bradoctor/blog/blog-updates/lingerie-from-history-we-would-probably-never-wear-again/2012/02/02|date=2 February 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606063620/http://www.nowthatslingerie.com/bradoctor/blog/blog-updates/lingerie-from-history-we-would-probably-never-wear-again/2012/02/02|archivedate=6 June 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Bullet bras allowed women to add a cup size to their bust.
[[Training bra|Bras]] for pre-teen and girls entering puberty were first marketed during the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web |title=Teen Bras |url=http://www.herroom.com/teen-bras,bras,794,001,10.html |publisher=HerRoom.com |accessdate=17 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116052407/http://www.herroom.com/teen-bras,bras,794,001,10.html |archivedate=16 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Prior to the introduction of training bras, young girls in Western countries usually wore a one-piece "waist" or [[camisole]] without cups or darts.
===The 1960s=== The 1960s reflected increasing interest in quality and fashion. Maternity and mastectomy bras began to find a new respectability, and the increasing use of washing machines created a need for products that were more durable. While girdles gave way to pantyhose, the bra continued to evolve. Marketing campaigns like those for the "Snoozable" and "Sweet Dreams" <ref>Maidenform Sweet Dreams Campaign (November 1962). Family Circle Magazine.</ref> promoted wearing a bra 24 hours a day.
In 1968 at the feminist [[Miss America protest]], protestors symbolically threw a number of feminine products into a "Freedom Trash Can." These included bras,<ref>{{cite journal | author=Dow, Bonnie J. |title=Feminism, Miss America, and Media Mythology |journal=Rhetoric & Public Affairs |volume=6 |issue=1 |date= Spring 2003 |pages=127–149 |doi=10.1353/rap.2003.0028}}</ref> which were among items the protestors called "instruments of female torture"<ref>{{cite book|author=Duffett, Judith |title=WLM vs. Miss America |work=Voice of the Women's Liberation Movement |date=October 1968 |page=4}}</ref> and accouterments of what they perceived to be enforced [[femininity]]. A local news story in the Atlantic City ''Press'' erroneously reported that "the bras, girdles, falsies, curlers, and copies of popular women's magazines burned in the 'Freedom Trash Can'".<ref>{{cite news|last=Boucher |first=John L. |title=Bra-Burners Blitz Boardwalk |work=(Atlantic City) Press |date=September 8, 1968}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Campbell |first=W. Joseph |title=Getting It Wrong: Ten of the Greatest Misreported Stories in American Journalism |publisher=University of California Press |pages=109–110|isbn=9780520262096|year=2010}}</ref> Individuals who were present said that no one burned a bra nor did anyone take off her bra.<ref name="Collins, Gail 2003">{{cite book |last=Collins |first=Gail |title=America's Women |publisher=HarperCollins |location= New York |year= 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Duffett |first=Judith |title=WLM vs. Miss America |work=Voice of the Women's Liberation Movement |date=October 1968 }}</ref>{{rp|4}} However, a female reporter (Lindsy Van Gelder) covering the protest drew an analogy between the feminist protesters and [[Vietnam War]] protesters who [[Draft-card burning|burned their draft cards]], and the parallel between protesters burning their draft cards and women burning their bras was encouraged by some organizers including [[Robin Morgan]]. "The media picked up on the bra part," [[Carol Hanisch]] said later. "I often say that if they had called us 'girdle burners,' every woman in America would have run to join us."<ref name=Greenfieldboyce>{{cite web|last=Greenfieldboyce|first=Nell|title=Pageant Protest Sparked Bra-Burning Myth|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94240375&from=mobile|publisher=NPR|accessdate=6 February 2012|date=September 5, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109083508/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94240375&from=mobile|archive-date=9 November 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Collins, Gail 2003"/>
Feminism and "bra-burning" became linked in popular culture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://radioequalizer.blogspot.com/2006/09/rush-limbaugh-gloria-steinem-jane.html |publisher=Radio Equalizer |date=14 September 2006 |title=Rush Blasts Greenstone |access-date=20 November 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616231246/http://radioequalizer.blogspot.com/2006/09/rush-limbaugh-gloria-steinem-jane.html |archive-date=16 June 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://heuriskein.blogspot.com/2006/01/so-called-ginsburg-standard.html |publisher=heuriskein |date=9 January 2006 |title=The so-called "Ginsburg standard" |access-date=20 November 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616231251/http://heuriskein.blogspot.com/2006/01/so-called-ginsburg-standard.html |archive-date=16 June 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The analogous term "jockstrap-burning" has since been coined as a reference to [[masculism]]. <ref name="jockburning">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-07-31/news/mn-29889_1_male-contraception|title=Search for Male Contraceptive Makes Gains|access-date=24 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217063442/http://articles.latimes.com/1995-07-31/news/mn-29889_1_male-contraception|archive-date=17 February 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> While feminist women did not literally burn their bras, some stopped wearing them in protest.{{sfn|Kornblum|2011}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hipmama.com/node/755 |title=Motherhood, Feminism and the Graveyard of Unwearable Bras |first=Violet A. |last=Shearer |accessdate=7 April 2010 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/61CnjNVJO?url=http://www.hipmama.com/node/755 |archive-date=25 August 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Author and feminist Bonnie J. Dow has suggested that the association between feminism and bra-burning was encouraged by individuals who opposed the feminist movement. "Bra-burning" created an image that women weren't really seeking freedom from sexism, but were attempting to assert themselves as sexual beings. This might lead individuals to believe, as she wrote in her 2003 article "Feminism, Miss America, and Media Mythology," that the women were merely trying to be "trendy, and to attract men."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dow |first=Bonnie J. |title=Feminism, Miss America, and Media Mythology |journal= Rhetoric & Public Affairs |volume=6 | issue = 1| year=2003|pages=127–149 |doi=10.1353/rap.2003.0028}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/unknown/viewarticle.aspx?id=299050 |author=Loughran, Jane |title=You don't have to be a bra-burning feminist to want to keep your name |publisher=News & Star |date=01/11/2005 |access-date=20 November 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230647/http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/unknown/viewarticle.aspx?id=299050 |archive-date=27 September 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://menz.org.nz/menz-issues/october-1996 |last=Williams |first=Ginny |title=Women of Goodwill |publisher=MENZ Issues |date=October 1996 |volume=1 |issue=4 |access-date=20 November 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180717013212/https://menz.org.nz/menz-issues/october-1996/ |archive-date=17 July 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Spongberg |first=Mary|title=If she's so great, how come so many pigs dig her? Germaine Greer and the malestream press|work=[[Women's History Review]] |volume=2| issue=3 |date=September 1993}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Campo |first=Natasha|title=Having it all’ or ‘had enough’? Blaming Feminism in the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald, 1980–2004. |journal=Journal of Australian Studies |issue=84|year=2005}}</ref> Women associated with an act like symbolically burning their bra may be seen by some as law-breaking radicals, eager to shock the public. This view may have supported the efforts of opponents to feminism and their desire to invalidate the movement.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gold |first=Jodi |author2=Susan Villari |title=Just Sex: Students Rewrite the Rules on Sex, Violence, Activism, and Equality|location=Maryland|publisher=Rowman and Littlefield |isbn=0847693333|year=2000}}</ref><!--if citing opinion, use quotes --> Some feminist activists believe that [[anti-feminist]]s use the bra burning myth and the subject of going braless to trivialize what the protesters were trying to accomplish at the feminist 1968 [[Miss America protest]] and the feminist movement in general.<ref>Lee, Jennifer [http://time.com/2853184/feminism-has-a-bra-burning-myth-problem Feminism Has a Bra-Burning Myth Problem] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180723220901/http://time.com/2853184/feminism-has-a-bra-burning-myth-problem/ |date=23 July 2018 }} June 11, 2014 ''Time''</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Dow |first=Bonnie J. |title=Spectacle, spectatorship, and gender anxiety in television news coverage of the 1970 women's strike for equality|work=Communication Studies |volume=50|pages=143–57|year=1999}}</ref><ref name=burnbra>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/history/american/burnbra.htm |title=Red Hot Mamas (bra-burning) |publisher=Snopes.com Urban Legends}}</ref>
==== Swimsuit and bra designs ====
[[File:Circa 1975 Wonderbra.jpg|180px|thumb|upright|A Canadian Wonderbra branded plunge, push-up bra, circa 1975]]
On June 4, 1962, [[Rudy Gernreich]]'s single-piece, topless [[monokini]] swimsuit received worldwide media attention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gernreich.steirischerbst.at/pages/bio1.htm|title=Gernreich Bio|publisher=Gernreich.steirischerbst.at|date=|accessdate=12 November 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213205151/http://gernreich.steirischerbst.at/pages/bio1.htm|archivedate=13 February 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Feitelberg|first=Rosemary|title=Moment 20: Bikinis Beckon|publisher=Women's Wear Daily|date=November 1, 2010|url=http://www.wwd.com/eye/fashion/moment-20-bikinis-beckon-3344816?navSection=package&navId=3343359|accessdate=22 January 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219182751/http://www.wwd.com/eye/fashion/moment-20-bikinis-beckon-3344816?navSection=package&navId=3343359|archivedate=19 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In its December 1962 issue, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' remarked, "He has turned the dancer's leotard into a swimsuit that frees the body. In the process, he has ripped out the boning and wiring that made American swimsuits seagoing corsets."<ref name=si1962>{{cite web|title=Way Out Out West: New Designs For The Sea...|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1135096/index.htm|publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=December 24, 1962|accessdate=23 January 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107204351/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1135096/index.htm|archivedate=7 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Gernreich followed that in October 1964 with the "No Bra", a soft-cup, light-weight, seamless, sheer nylon and elastic tricot bra in sizes 32 to 36, A and B cups, manufactured by Exquisite Form. His minimalist bra was a revolutionary departure from the heavy, torpedo-shaped bras of the 1950s, initiating a trend toward more natural shapes and soft, sheer fabrics.<ref>{{cite web|title=The "No Bra" Brassiere|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O64190/the-no-bra-brassiere-bra-gernreich-rudi/|publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum|accessdate=18 March 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006013311/http://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O64190/the-no-bra-brassiere-bra-gernreich-rudi|archivedate=6 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Foreman|first1=Katya|title=The Bra: an Uplifting Tale|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20150220-the-bra-an-uplifting-tale|accessdate=12 October 2015|publisher=BBC|date=20 February 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009025019/http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20150220-the-bra-an-uplifting-tale|archivedate=9 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He also designed an "All-in-None" design with a deep, plunging front, and a "No-Back" long-line version, which featured a contoured stretch-waistband that allowed a woman to wear a backless dress.<ref>{{cite news |title=Rudi Gernreich's 'No-Bra ' Bra… Comes In Threes |date=October 1965 |url=http://blog.modernmechanix.com/rudi-gernreichs-no-bra-bra-comes-in-threes-slightly-nsfw/ |newspaper=[[Playgirl]] |pages=32–35 |accessdate=May 30, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318224906/http://blog.modernmechanix.com/rudi-gernreichs-no-bra-bra-comes-in-threes-slightly-nsfw/ |archivedate=18 March 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The [[Wonderbra]] was created in 1964 by Louise Poirier for Canadelle, a Canadian lingerie company. It has 54 design elements that lift and support the bustline while creating a deep plunge and push-together effect. First-year sales for the Wonderbra were approximated at US$120 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~afuah/cases/case15.html |title=Wonderbra Story |publisher=University of Michigan Business School |first1=Matthew |last1=Moberg |author2=Jonathan Siskin, Barry Stern |year=1999 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111060318/http://www-personal.umich.edu/~afuah/cases/case15.html |archivedate=11 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They repositioned [[Wonderbra#Canadian product.2C 1964-1980|Wonderbra]] as a romantic, fashionable and sexy brand.<ref>{{cite book | last1= Mintzberg | first1 = Henry | authorlink = Henry Mintzberg |author2= James Waters | title = Researching the Formation of Strategies: The History of Canadian Lady, 1939–1976 ''in R.B. Lamb (ed.) Competitive Strategic Management'' | publisher = Prentice Hall | year = 1984 | location = New York | isbn = 0-13-154972-3 | page = 70}}</ref>
===The 1970s === {{Original research|section=1|date=February 2016}} [[Germaine Greer]]'s book ''[[The Female Eunuch]]'' (1970) became associated with the anti-bra movement because she pointed out how restrictive and uncomfortable a bra could be. "Bras are a ludicrous invention", she wrote, "but if you make bralessness a rule, you're just subjecting yourself to yet another repression."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.biographyonline.net/writers/germaine-greer.html | title=German Greer Biography | accessdate=7 April 2010 | archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/61Cnil4GK?url=http://www.biographyonline.net/writers/germaine-greer.html | archive-date=25 August 2011 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In the 1970s, like other garment makers, bra manufacturers moved production offshore. The evolution of the bra reflects the constantly changing idea of what an "ideal" woman should look like{{spaced ndash}}flat, round, pointy, conical, or even "natural". The contemporary bra also reflects advances in manufacturing and availability of fabric types and colours, enabling it to be transformed from a utilitarian item to a fashion statement, countering the negative attitudes some women had about bras. Designers have also incorporated numerous devices to produce varying shapes, cleavage, and to give women bras they could wear with open-back dresses, off-the-shoulder dresses, plunging necklines, and the like.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}
=== The 1980s ===
Throughout the 1980s fashion led the way in the look and feel of bras. Western TV shows featured classy, powerful, and well-formed ladies, usually donning low cut tops to show an enhanced chest with an equally classy matching bra.
The onset of classy and stylish Teddy suits also encompassed this decade and sales of silicone increased the need for bigger and more supportive bras.
Models and celebrities all donned fashionable and extravagant bras, showing these off at red carpets events become the norm. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uklingerie.com/blog/history-of-the-bra/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170926211927/https://www.uklingerie.com/blog/history-of-the-bra/ |archivedate=26 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In contrast, feminist [[Susan Brownmiller]] in her book ''Femininity'' (1984) took the position that women without bras shock and anger men because men "implicitly think that they own breasts and that only they should remove bras."{{sfn|Young|2005|p=192}}
=== The 1990s === [[File:JogBra DSCF2208.jpg | thumb|right | JogBra]] Manufacturers' marketing and advertising often appeals to fashion and image over fit, comfort and function.<ref name="mintel" /><ref name="McGhee">{{cite book|last=McGhee|first=DE|others=Steele JR|title=How do respiratory state and measurement method affect bra size calculations?|publisher=Sports Medicine|year=2006|volume=40|pages=970–974}}</ref> Since about 1994, manufacturers have re-focused their advertising, moving from advertising functional bras that emphasize support and foundation, to selling lingerie that emphasize fashion while sacrificing basic fit and function, like linings under scratchy lace.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/13/opinion/13SEIG.html |title=The Cups Runneth Over |last=Seigel |first=Jessica |date=13 February 2004 |work=New York Times |accessdate=26 April 2010 |location=New York |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423163138/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/13/opinion/13SEIG.html |archivedate=23 April 2009 }}</ref>
With the growing popularity of jogging and other forms of exercise, it became apparent that there was a need for an athletic garment for women's breasts. In 1977, [[Lisa Lindahl]], [[Polly Smith]] and [[Hinda Mille]] invented the first sports bra<ref name="Distillations">{{cite journal |last1=Roberts |first1=Jacob |title=Women's work |journal=Distillations |date=2017 |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=6–11 |url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/magazine/womens-work |accessdate=22 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323154959/https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/magazine/womens-work |archive-date=23 March 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in the costume shop of Royall Tyler Theatre at the [[University of Vermont]]. One of the original [[Sports bra|Jogbra]]s is bronzed and on display near the costume shop of the theatre. Two others are housed by the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian]] and another by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art|New York Metropolitan Museum of Art]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uvm.edu/~uvmpr/?Page=article.php&id=1598 |title=History-Changing Garment Born in Theater Costume Shop |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516195454/http://www.uvm.edu/~uvmpr/?Page=article.php&id=1598 |archivedate=16 May 2014 |df=dmy-all |access-date=17 March 2012 }}</ref>
=== The 2000s ===
Two design challenges that bra manufacturers face at present seem paradoxical. On the one hand, there is a demand for minimal bras that allow plunging necklines and reduce interference with the lines of outer garments, such as the [[Bra#Types of bras|shelf bra]]. On the other hand, body mass and bust size is increasing,<ref name="seigel">{{cite web |url=http://www.jessicaseigel.com/articles/bra.shtml |author=Jessica Seigel |title=Bent out of shape: Why is it so hard to find the perfect bra? |work=Lifetime Magazine |date=May–June 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61Cnpilky?url=http://www.jessicaseigel.com/articles/bra.shtml |archivedate=25 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> leading to a higher demand for larger sizes.<ref name="king">{{cite news|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20050602/ai_n14651255 |author=King, Stephanie |title=A short history of lingerie: Doreen the bra that conquered the world |work=The Independent |date=2 June 2005|quote=See Victoria Hiley, ''Bra-burning a myth'' 4 June. Commentary on Stephanie King, A short history of lingerie. 2 June 2005}}</ref> Over a 10-year period, the most common size purchased in the UK went from 34B to 36C. In 2001, 27% of UK sales were D or larger.<ref name="mintel">{{cite web |url=http://reports.mintel.com/sinatra/reports/display/id=125741 |title=Bras and Pants |publisher=Mintel International Group Ltd. |date=2001, 2005 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101109092316/http://reports.mintel.com/sinatra/reports/display/id=125741 |archivedate=9 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="casselman">{{cite journal |url=http://www.discover.com/issues/nov-05/departments/physics-of-bras/ |author=Anne Casselman |title=The Physics of Bras |publisher=DISCOVER |volume=26 |issue=11 |date=November 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20051029014224/http://www.discover.com/issues/nov-05/departments/physics-of-bras/ |archivedate=29 October 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The 2000s brought two large design changes to the bra.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The molded one-piece, seamless bra cup became ubiquitous.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} They are heat-molded around round forms of synthetic fibers or foam that keeps their rounded shape. This construction can include padded bras, contour bras and so-called T-shirt bras. Also new and ubiquitous in the 2000s was the popularity of printed designs such as floral or patterned prints.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Bras are a billion-dollar industry ($15 billion in the US in 2001, £1 billion in UK.<ref name="mintel"/>) that continues to grow. Large corporations such as [[HanesBrands Inc.]] control most bra manufacturing,<ref name="mintel"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hanesbrands.com/hbi/en-us/ |title=Hanesbrands|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114111939/http://www.hanesbrands.com/hbi/en-us/ |archivedate=14 November 2006 }}</ref> Gossard, [[Berlei]] and Courtaulds with 34% of the UK market. [[Victoria's Secret]] is an exception.
Feminist author [[Iris Marion Young]] wrote in 2005 that the bra "serves as a barrier to touch" and that a braless woman is "[[Sexual objectification|deobjectified]]", eliminating the "hard, pointy look that phallic culture posits as the norm." Without a bra, in her view, women's breasts are not consistently shaped objects but change as the woman moves, reflecting the natural body.{{sfn|Young|2005|p=192}} Other feminist anti-bra arguments from Young in 2005 include that [[training bra]]s are used to indoctrinate girls into thinking about their breasts as sexual objects and to accentuate their sexuality.{{sfn|Young|2005|p=192}} Young also wrote in 2007 that, in American culture, breasts are subject to "[c]apitalist, [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] American media-dominated culture [that] objectifies breasts before such a distancing glance that freezes and masters."{{sfn|Burns-Ardolino|2007|p=31}} Academic Wendy Burns-Ardolino wrote in 2007 that women's decision to wear bras is mediated by the "[[male gaze]]".{{sfn|Burns-Ardolino|2007|pp=30–32}}
===Modern production===
Like other clothing, bras were initially sewn by small production companies and supplied to various retailers. The term "cup" was not used to describe bras until 1916, and manufacturers relied on stretchable cups to accommodate different sized breasts.<ref name=farrell>{{cite book |title=Uplift: The Bra in America |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtRbdACUkqgC |first1=Jane |last1=Farrell-Beck |first2=Colleen |last2=Gau |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |edition=illustrated |date=22 October 2002 |isbn=978-0-8122-1835-0 |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723035935/https://books.google.com/books?id=MtRbdACUkqgC |archivedate=23 July 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>{{rp|73}} Women with larger or pendulous breasts had the choice of long-line bras, built-up backs, wedge-shaped inserts between the cups, wider straps, power Lastex, firm bands under the cup, and even light boning.
In October 1932, the S.H. Camp and Company correlated the size and pendulousness of a woman's breasts to letters of the alphabet: A, B, C and D. Camp's advertising featured letter-labeled profiles of breasts in the February 1933 issue of ''Corset and Underwear Review''.<ref>{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_h5-Ov5fm8&feature=related |title=How to Measure for a Bra |publisher=HerRoom.com |date=9 June 2009 |accessdate=19 January 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831163645/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_h5-Ov5fm8&feature=related |archivedate=31 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 1937, Warner began to feature cup sizing in its products. Adjustable bands were introduced using multiple eye and hook positions in the 1930s.<ref name=farrell/><ref>{{cite book |title=The Lingerie Handbook |first=Rebecca |last=Apsan |others=Sarah Stark |page=186 |publisher=Workman Publishing Company |date=20 October 2006 |isbn=0-7611-4323-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KBobur5ZgX0C&pg=PA30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512203239/http://books.google.com/books?id=KBobur5ZgX0C&pg=PA30 |archivedate=12 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=steele>{{cite book |title=The Berg Companion to Fashion |first=Valerie |last=Steele |pages=800 pages |publisher=Berg Publishers |date=9 November 2010 |isbn=978-1-84788-592-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hemsvn9ZbRkC&pg=PA101 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712030047/http://books.google.com/books?id=Hemsvn9ZbRkC&pg=PA101 |archivedate=12 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>{{rp|101}}
There is an [[urban legend]] that the bra was invented by a man named [[Otto Titzling]] ("tit sling") who lost a lawsuit with ''Phillip de Bra'' ("fill up the bra"). This originated with the 1971 book ''Bust-Up: The Uplifting Tale of Otto Titzling and the Development of the Bra'' and was propagated in a comedic song from the movie ''[[Beaches (film)|Beaches]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/business/origins/bra.asp|title= Brassiere (origin of name)|publisher=Snopes.com Urban Legends}}</ref>
==Future of bras== In 1964, Danish Fashion historian [[Rudolf Broby-Johansen|Rudolf Kristian Albert Broby-Johansen]] wrote that the topless look, which liberated breasts from bras, should be treated seriously. He asserted that it was a way for a new generation of women to express themselves. In 1969, he wrote an article titled "Obituary for the Bra" in which he predicted the imminent demise of bras.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Thesander | first1 = Marianne. | title = The Feminine Idea | year = 1997 | publisher = Reaktion Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-86189-004-7 | pages =232 }}</ref>
Brassieres are worn by the great majority of women in Western society. Estimates about what proportion of [[Western culture|Western]] women wear bras varies, but most surveys report from 75% to 95%. About 90% of Australian women wear a bra as of 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antibra.com/why_wear_bras.php |title=Why wear a bra? |accessdate=2 May 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513140505/http://www.antibra.com/why_wear_bras.php |archivedate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> There are now an unprecedented array of [[list of brassiere designs|styles and models]], including full-coverage bras, [[Balconette brassiere|balconette cup bras]], and [[sports bra]]s that can sometimes be worn as outerwear. Women, health professionals, feminists and fashion writers appear to be increasingly questioning its place and function, and asking whether it will go the way of pantyhose, garter belts and stockings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abramsbooks.com/Books/Hoorah_for_the_Bra-9781584795278.html |author1=Berry, Cheree |title=Hoorah for the Bra |last2=Abrams |year=2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728052647/http://www.abramsbooks.com/Books/Hoorah_for_the_Bra-9781584795278.html |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.007b.com/why_wear_bras.php |publisher=007 |title=Why Women wear bras |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61Cnk7C8i?url=http://www.007b.com/why_wear_bras.php |archivedate=25 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Why we don't wear bras |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/WHY+WE+DON%27T+WEAR+BRAS%3B+Women+busting+out+like+Liz.-a061095128 |work=Daily Mirror |date=30 July 1997}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Dickinson, Amy |title=It's a wonder why women still wear bras |work=Chicago Tribune |date=27 October 2006}}</ref>
It is now commonplace to see models and other celebrities who do not wear bras in public,<ref>{{cite news |first=Jeannine|last= Stein|title= Bras scarce on fashion show runways |publisher= Seattle Post-Intelligencer|date=15 July 2002}}</ref> including [[Britney Spears]],<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1259146/Britney-Spears-usual-unkempt-self-shopping-trip-Hollywood.html |title=No bra, price tags on her clothes and messy hair ... just another day out for Britney Spears as she hits the shops |date=19 March 2010 |publisher=Daily Mail Online |accessdate=26 April 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729095225/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1259146/Britney-Spears-usual-unkempt-self-shopping-trip-Hollywood.html |archivedate=29 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Claire Danes]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://images.le-bouzin.com/claire-danes/le-nippleslip-de-claire-danes/|title=Le nippleslip de Claire Danes|language=French|accessdate=24 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603124618/http://images.le-bouzin.com/claire-danes/le-nippleslip-de-claire-danes/|archivedate=3 June 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Lindsay Lohan]],<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1222446/Braless-Lindsay-Lohan-hangs-shopping-spree.html |title=Lindsay Lohan exposes her shortage of underwear during revealing shopping spree |date=24 October 2009 |publisher=Daily Mail Online |accessdate=26 April 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120803041648/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1222446/Braless-Lindsay-Lohan-hangs-shopping-spree.html |archivedate=3 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[Nadine Coyle]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1208648/Braless-Nadine-Coyle-steals-Kings-Of-Leon-gig.html|title=Braless Nadine Coyle steals the show at Kings of Leon gig (and it's not bad for her solo career either)|date=24 August 2009|publisher=Daily Mail Online|accessdate=26 April 2010|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120723212335/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1208648/Braless-Nadine-Coyle-steals-Kings-Of-Leon-gig.html|archivedate=23 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Many outergarments like sundresses, tank tops, and formal evening wear are designed to be worn without bras.<ref name=brasontop>{{cite web |url=http://www.brasontop.com/bras/a-brief-history-of-the-bra/ |title=A Brief History of Bras |publisher=Bras On Top |accessdate=1 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317130450/http://www.brasontop.com/bras/a-brief-history-of-the-bra/ |archivedate=17 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Fashion writers continue to suggest alternatives to bras or ways of dressing without bras, emphasising that wearing a bra is a matter of choice and not a requirement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lemondrop.com/2008/10/20/test-drive-tools-for-going-braless/ |author=Erin Donnelly |title=Trend Test Drive: Going Braless |publisher=Lemondrop |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713201208/http://www.lemondrop.com/2008/10/20/test-drive-tools-for-going-braless/ |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Given the discomfort women experience with ill-fitting bras, an increasing number of women, once they are home, are switching to undershirts, jogbras, or nothing at all.<ref name=angel>{{cite web |url=http://angelasancartier.net/brassiere |title=Brassiere |publisher=Clothing and Fashion Encyclopedia |accessdate=19 January 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129043157/http://angelasancartier.net/brassiere |archivedate=29 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Unhappy bra owners have donated thousands of bras to the Braball Sculpture, a collection of 18,085 bras.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.braball.com/thanks.htm |title=The Braball, Thanks |publisher=Emily Duffy |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708090255/http://www.braball.com/thanks.htm |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The organizer, Emily Duffy, wears a 42B and switched to stretch undershirts with built-in bras because standard bras cut her midsection.<ref name="seigel"/>
