Although [[Victorian restoration|restored]] in the 19th century it is one of the best preserved mediaeval windows in Somerset. Additionally it is unusual in that the window contains a full set of glass from the same period. The church is no longer used for services, its congregation has been merged with nearby St Mary's.{{cite web |url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/all-saints-langport.html |title=All Saints' Church, Langport, Somerset|accessdate=16 October 2016 |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]] }} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|a|I}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Church of St Mary, Seavington St Mary|St Mary]],
[[Seavington St Mary]] |[[Somerset]]
{{coord|50.9306|-2.8511|name=Church of St Mary, Seavington St Mary}} |[[File:Seavington St Mary church.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|66|15th century}} |The former [[Anglican]] parish Church of St Mary has 13th-century origins, but the present building is from the late 15th century, with [[Victorian restoration|restoration]] around 1880. The three-stage tower is from the 16th century.{{NHLE |num= 1307339|desc=Church of St Mary, Seavington St Mary|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} It was previously held as a chapelry of [[South Petherton]] by [[Bruton Abbey]] and after the [[dissolution of the monasteries]] belonged to [[Bristol Cathedral]].{{cite book|last=Bush|first=Robin|title=Somerset: The Complete Guide|publisher=Dovecote Press|authorlink=Robin Bush (historian)|year=1994|page=176|isbn=1-874336-26-1}} Since 1983 it has been declared a [[redundant church]].{{cite web|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-mary-seavington.html |title=St Mary's Church, Seavington, Somerset|publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St Mary's Church, Wilton|St Mary]],
[[Wilton, Wiltshire|Wilton]] |[[Wiltshire]]
{{coord|51.0797|-1.8633|name=St Mary's Church, Wilton}} |[[File:St Mary, Wilton.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|67|15th century}} |St Marys was built on the site of an earlier church at which Bishop [[Robert de Bingham]] was consecrated in 1229 before the completion of his [[Salisbury Cathedral|cathedral]] church at [[Salisbury]]. By the 9th century the [[Benedictine]] [[convent]] of [[Wilton Abbey]] was attached to the church.{{NHLE |num= 1355781|desc=Church of St Mary, Wilton|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} During the 14th and 15th centuries other mediaeval churches in Wilton closed and combined with St Mary's which was rebuilt and expanded to become, by the 16th century, the sole parish church. The old church was partially demolished, apart from the [[chancel]] and one bay of the [[nave]]. The ruins of the three arches of the south arcade, and fragments of the north arcade and the altered eastern arch of the west tower or west window remain within the churchyard.{{cite web|title=St Mary's Church, Wilton, Wiltshire|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-mary-wilton.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} Restoration was undertaken between 1933 and 1939, by [[Robert Worth Bingham]], who was the [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] from 1933 to 1937 and claimed descent from [[Robert de Bingham]]. The church was made [[Redundant church|redundant]] in 1972. !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Old St Cuthbert's Church, Oborne|Old Church of St Cuthbert]],
[[Oborne]] |[[Dorset]]
{{coord|50.9589|-2.4939|name=Old St Cuthbert's Church, Oborne}} |[[File:Oborne old church 02.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|69|1533}} |Only the [[chancel]] remains of St Cuthbert's Church,{{NHLE |num= 1304077|desc=Old Parish Church of St Cuthbert, Oborne|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} which would have been one of the last to be built before the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]], following the demolition of the [[nave]] in the 1860s. The neglected chancel was restored in the 1930s. The interior includes [[mediaeval]] slip tiles and communion rails, pulpit and monuments from the 17th century. The pillar [[piscina]] and [[Baptismal font|font]] were brought to St Cuthbert's from [[North Wootton, Dorset|North Wootton]].{{cite web|title=St Cuthbert Old Chancel, Oborne, Dorset|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-cuthbert-oborne.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} A new parish church, designed by William Slater, was built on a fresh site in the villages and consecrated in 1862.{{NHLE |num= 1119358|desc=Parish Church of St Cuthbert, Oborne|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Church of St. Andrew, Holcombe|St Andrew]],
[[Holcombe, Somerset|Holcombe]] |[[Somerset]]
{{coord|51.2547|-2.4758|name=Church of St. Andrew, Holcombe}} |[[File:Holcombe Old St Andrews church.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|70|16th century}} |The church has late [[Anglo-Saxons|Saxon]]-early [[Norman architecture|Norman]] origins and was rebuilt in the 16th century, with a two-stage tower and two bay [[nave]].{{NHLE |num= 1058677|desc=Church of St Andrew, Holcombe|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} The interior includes late [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] box pews and a [[Jacobean architecture|Jacobean]] [[pulpit]].{{cite web|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-andrew-holcombe.html |title=St Andrew's Church, Holcombe, Somerset|publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St George's Church, Portland|St George]],
[[Isle of Portland]] |[[Dorset]]
{{coord|50.547|-2.4438|name=St George's Church, Portland}} |[[File:Uk dor weston.JPG|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|72|1754–1766}} |St George's Church was built to replace [[St Andrew's Church, Portland|St Andrew's]] which had fallen into disuse and was no longer suitable as a place of worship.{{cite web|title=St George's Church, Portland, Dorset|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-george-portland.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} The church was closed in 1914 and fell into further disrepair until restoration in the 1960s. It is a large church built of [[Portland stone]] and has a tower, a nave, transepts, an apse, and a dome over the crossing.{{NHLE |num= 1203132|desc=Church of St George, Reforne|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}}{{cite book | last1 = Newman | first1= John | authorlink2=|first2=Nikolaus|last2= Pevsner | title = The Buildings of England, Dorset | publisher = Penguin Books | year = 1972 |page=341 | isbn = 0-14-071044-2}} !{{Grade II colour}}|{{sort|c|II}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St. Paul's Church, Bristol|St Paul]],
[[Portland Square, Bristol|Portland Square]] |[[Bristol]]
{{coord|51.4611|-2.5847|name=St Paul's Church, Bristol}} |[[File:St Paul's Church, Bristol.jpg|upright|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|74|1789–1794}} | It was designed by [[Daniel Hague]] and built in the 1790s but fell into disuse and disrepair by its closure in 1988.{{NHLE |num= 1282180|desc=Church of St Paul, Bristol|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} St Paul's became known as the Wedding Cake Church from the unusual tiered tower,{{cite web|title=St Paul's Church, Bristol, Bristol|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-paul-bristol.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} which was designed to hold a ring of ten [[Church bell|bells]]. About £2.3 million from the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] funded the restoration and conversion work.{{cite web | title=Draft Grants to the Churches Conservation Trust Order 2003 | work=House of Commons | url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200203/cmstand/deleg6/st030226/30226s01.htm | accessdate=22 February 2007}}{{cite web | title=Church converts | work=Christian Science Monitor | url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/0501/p11s01-lire.html?related | accessdate=22 February 2007}} In 2005 the church was converted into its present form as the home of [[Circomedia]], a circus school.{{cite web | title=Venue hire | url=http://www.circomedia.com/venue-hire/ | publisher=Circomedia | accessdate=27 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213171122/http://www.circomedia.com/venue-hire/ | archivedate=13 December 2010 | df=dmy-all }} It still boasts an ornate Georgian plaster ceiling, stone columns and a wealth of decorative [[stained glass]], but has now been equipped with aerial and [[trapeze]] equipment and a pale maple wood sprung dance floor.{{cite web|title=St Pauls Church, Bristol |work=Carreck Historic Building Conservation |url=http://www.carrek.co.uk/default.asp?categoryID=2&projectID=17 |accessdate=22 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817024654/http://www.carrek.co.uk/default.asp?categoryID=2&projectID=17 |archivedate=17 August 2007 |df= }} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|a|I}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Church of St Michael, Princetown|St Michael]],
[[Princetown]] |[[Devon]]
{{coord|50.5461|-3.9961|name=Church of St Michael, Princetown}} |[[File:St Michael and All Angels, Princetown.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|76|1810–1814}} |The [[granite]] Church of St Michael, which is sometimes known as St Michael and All Angels church stands near the middle of [[Dartmoor]], close to [[Dartmoor (HM Prison)|Dartmoor Prison]].{{NHLE |num= 1105434|desc=Church of St Michael, Princetown|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} The church was designed by the architect Daniel Alexander and built by prisoners from the [[Napoleonic Wars]] and finished by those captured during the [[War of 1812|American war]] who were held in the prison,{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Sophie|title=Dartmoor prison turns to captivating tourists|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/familyholidays/5251563/Dartmoor-prison-turns-to-captivating-tourists.html|accessdate=17 October 2010|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=1 May 2009}}{{cite web|title=Potted History of Princetown|url=http://www.hmca.org.uk/history/index.html|publisher=High Moorland Community Action Ltd|accessdate=17 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107074219/http://www.hmca.org.uk/history/index.html|archivedate=7 January 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Princetown Church|url=http://www.legendarydartmoor.co.uk/prince_church.htm|publisher=Legendary Dartmoor|accessdate=21 September 2017}} and is the only church in England to have been built by [[prisoners of war]].{{cite web|title=Church of St Michael & All Angels, Princetown, Devon|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-michael-and-all-angels-princetown.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} The church remained in service until 1992 when it was declared [[Redundant church|redundant]]. !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St Peter's Church, Everleigh|St Peter]],
[[Everleigh, Wiltshire|Everleigh]] |[[Wiltshire]]
{{coord|51.2864|-1.7172|name=St Peter's Church, Everleigh}} |[[File:St Peter, Everleigh- October 2014 (geograph 4252833).jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|78|1813}} |Everleigh had a parish church by 1228, when it was granted to the [[Order of Saint Benedict|Benedictine]] [[Wherwell Abbey]] in Hampshire.{{cite book |title=[[Victoria County History]]: A History of the County of Wiltshire: Volume 10: Downton hundred; Elstub and Everleigh Hundred |last1=Crowley |first1=D.A. (ed.) |last2=Baggs |first2=A.P. |last3=Crittall |first3=Elizabeth |last4=Freeman |first4=Jane |last5=Stevenson |first5=Janet H.|year=1980 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |pages=135–142}} However, the mediaeval parish church was demolished in 1814 when the present [[Church of England parish church]] of [[Saint Peter]], built by John Morlidge for F.D. Astley, was consecrated on a site about {{convert|0.5|mi|m}} north west of it. The present church was designed by the architect John Morlidge in a [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] style.{{cite web|title=St Peter's Church, Everleigh, Wiltshire|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-peter-everleigh.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}}{{cite book |last1=Pevsner |first1=Nikolaus |authorlink1=Nikolaus Pevsner |last2=Cherry |first2=Bridget (revision) |title=[[Pevsner Architectural Guides#Buildings of England|The Buildings of England]]: Wiltshire |year=1975 |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |location=Harmondsworth |isbn=0140710264 |page=242}} It includes the original [[Norman architecture|Norman]] [[Baptismal font|font]] from the old church. It has many memorials to the [[Sir John Astley, 1st Baronet|Astley family]].{{NHLE |num= 1035994|desc=Church of St Peter, Everleigh|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sutton Mallet Church]],
Sutton Mallet, [[Stawell, Somerset|Stawell]] |[[Somerset]]
{{coord|51.1283|-2.8978|name=Sutton Mallet Church}} |[[File:Church at Sutton Mallet - geograph.org.uk - 191104.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|80|1827–1829}} |The current church was built between 1827 and 1829 by Richard Carver of [[Taunton]] adjoining the old tower.{{NHLE |num= 1174207|desc=Sutton Mallet Church|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} Although the rebuilding was in a [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] style, remnants from the earlier church were reused including a mediaeval window which was incorporated into the small [[apse]].{{cite web|title=The Church (no dedication), Sutton Mallet, Somerset|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/the-church-sutton-mallet.html |work=Projects|publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} In 1987 the church was transferred to the Redundant Churches Fund.{{cite web| title=Sutton Mallet |work= A History of the County of Somerset: Volume 8: The Poldens and the Levels |year=2004| pages=184–190 |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=15117 |accessdate=26 July 2010}} !{{Grade II colour}}|{{sort|c|II}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St Margaret of Antioch Church, Leigh Delamere|St Margaret of Antioch]],
[[Leigh Delamere]] |[[Wiltshire]]
{{coord|51.5122|-2.1678|name=St Margaret of Antioch Church, Leigh Delamere}} |[[File:St. Margaret's Church, Leigh Delamere - geograph.org.uk - 123903.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|82|1846}} |The earlier church was built in about 1190, in an [[Early English Gothic|Early English]] style with some [[Norman architecture|Norman]] features. In 1301 the patron of the church was [[John De la Mare]]. By 1846 the church was in a dilapidated condition and it would have cost more to repair than to rebuild.{{cite web|title=Church of St Margaret, Leigh Delamere|url=http://history.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getimage.php?id=4711|publisher=Wiltshire County Council|accessdate=7 October 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812030109/http://history.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getimage.php?id=4711|archive-date=12 August 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The new church was commissioned by [[Joseph Neeld]] and designed by James Thomson. The [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic]] [[chancel]] includes a [[reredos]] carved and decorated in many colours. The west window includes [[stained glass]] by Wilmshurst.{{cite web|title=Church of St Margaret of Antioch, Leigh Delamere, Wiltshire|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-margaret-leigh-delamere.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} The church contains many memorials, including those to the [[Neeld Baronets]].{{NHLE |num= 1022289|desc=Church of St Margaret, Grittleton|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} A new organ was installed in 1896, and electricity supplied in 1949, although by then attendance was very low. The church was closed as a regular place of worship in 1992. !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St Mary's Church, Chute Forest|St Mary]],
[[Chute Forest]] |[[Wiltshire]]
{{coord|51.2669|-1.5583|name=St Mary's Church, Chute Forest}} |[[File:St Marys Church Chute Forest.jpg|upright|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|84|1870–1871}} |St Mary's Church was consecrated in 1875.{{cite web|title=Chute Forest|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=23043#s5|work= A History of the County of Wiltshire: Volume 16: Kinwardstone Hundred |publisher=British History Online|accessdate=4 October 2010|pages=120–126|year=1999}} The church was built of [[flint]], brick and tile with a pyramid [[spire]], by [[John Loughborough Pearson]] for the Fowle family. The [[nave]] and [[aisle]]s are spanned by a single roof.{{cite web|title=St Mary's Church, Chute Forest, Wiltshire|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-mary-chute-forest.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}}{{NHLE |num= 1364574|desc=Church of St Mary, Chute Forest|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} It contains [[stained glass]] by [[Clayton and Bell]] a partnership of John Richard Clayton (London, 1827–1913) and Alfred Bell (Silton, Dorset, 1832–95).{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Sarah|title=Stained Glass – an Illustrated History |year=1994|publisher=Bracken Books|isbn=1-85891-157-5|page=132}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|b|II*}} |- ! scope="row"|[[St Mary's Church, South Tidworth|St Mary]],
South [[Tidworth]], |[[Wiltshire]]
{{coord|51.2283|-1.6644|name=St Mary's Church, South Tidworth}} |[[File:St Mary's, South Tidworth.jpg|100px]] | style="text-align:center;"|{{sort|86|1878}} |Built of rock-faced brown stone in a [[Gothic Revival]] style by John Johnson, the construction work was supervised by G. H. Gordon,{{cite web|title=Church of St Mary, South Tidworth|url=http://history.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getchurch.php?id=804|publisher=Wiltshire County Council|accessdate=16 October 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812030225/http://history.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getchurch.php?id=804|archive-date=12 August 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} for Sir John Kelk of the [[Kelk Baronets]].{{cite web|title=St Mary's Church, South Tidworth, Wiltshire|url= https://www.visitchurches.org.uk/visit/church-listing/st-mary-south-tidworth.html |publisher=[[Churches Conservation Trust]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}} The [[chancel]] is {{convert|28|x|17|ft|m}} and the [[nave]] {{convert|43|x|17|ft|m}}.{{NHLE |num= 1093240|desc=Church of St Mary,Tidworth|accessdate= 28 March 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none |fewer-links=x}} There are also north and south [[aisle]]s, a north vestry, and a south porch.{{cite web|last=Page|first=William|title=Parishes: Tidworth, South|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=56838#s3|work=A History of the County of Hampshire: Volume 4|publisher=British History Online|accessdate=16 October 2010|pages=391–394|year=1911}} The interior contains carvings and polished marble shafts in the columns of the arcade piers. The [[chancel]] floor is laid with [[Art of Italy|Italian]] mosaic. The church was declared [[Redundant church|redundant]] in 1972. !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|a|I}} |} ==See also== *[[List of churches preserved by the Churches Conservation Trust in the East of England]] *[[List of churches preserved by the Churches Conservation Trust in the English Midlands]] *[[List of churches preserved by the Churches Conservation Trust in Northern England]] *[[List of churches preserved by the Churches Conservation Trust in Southeast England]] ==Notes== {{note label|Location|A|A}}The dates given for construction are often not exactly known. Where this is the case the century of first construction of the existing building is given. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Churches Conservation Trust}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Architectural history lists|Churches Conservation Trust in Southwest England]] [[Category:Churches preserved by the Churches Conservation Trust|*]] [[Category:Lists of churches in England|Churches Conservation Trust in Southwest England]]

{{unreferenced|date=November 2014}} '''Mikhail Petrovich Pogodin''' ({{lang-ru|Михаи́л Петро́вич Пого́дин}}; {{OldStyleDate|23 November|1800|11 November}}{{spaced ndash}}{{OldStyleDate|20 December|1875|8 December}}) was a [[Russia]]n historian and journalist who, jointly with [[Nikolay Gerasimovich Ustryalov|Nikolay Ustryalov]], dominated the national historiography between the death of [[Nikolay Karamzin]] in 1826 and the rise of [[Sergey Solovyov]] in the 1850s. He is best remembered as a staunch proponent of the [[Normanist theory]] of Russian statehood. [[Image:Портрет историка Михаила Петровича Погодина.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Mikhail Pogodin.]]
Pogodin's father was a serf housekeeper of [[Count Stroganov]], and the latter ensured Mikhail's education in the [[Moscow University]]. As the story goes, Pogodin the student lived from hand to mouth, because he spent his whole stipend on purchasing new volumes of [[Nikolay Karamzin]]'s history of Russia.
Pogodin's early publications were panned by [[Mikhail Kachenovsky]], a Greek who held the university chair in Russian history. Misinterpreting [[August Ludwig von Schlözer|Schlozer]]'s novel teachings, Kachenovsky declared that "ancient Russians lived like mice or birds, they had neither money nor books" and that ''[[Primary Chronicle]]'' was a crude falsification from the era of Mongol ascendency. His teachings became exceedingly popular, spawning the so-called sceptical school of imperial historiography.
In 1823, Pogodin completed his dissertation in which he debunked Kachenovsky's idea of [[Khazar]] origin of [[Rurik]]id princes. He further stirred up the controversy by proclaiming that serious scholars should not only trust but worship [[Nestor the Chronicler|Nestor]]. The dispute ended with Kachenovsky's chair being devolved on Pogodin. In the 1830s and 1840s he augmented his reputation by publishing many volumes of obscure historical documents and the last part of [[Mikhail Shcherbatov]]'s history of Russia.
Towards the end of the 1830s, Pogodin turned his attention to journalism, where his career was likewise a slow burner. Between 1827 and 1830 he edited ''The Herald of Moscow'' with [[Alexander Pushkin]] as one of the regular contributors. Upon first meeting the great poet in 1826, Pogodin (in)famously remarked in his diary that "his mug doesn't look promising". However, this remark is usually taken out of context as Pogodin wrote glowing reviews of Pushkin's work as early as 1820.
In 1841 Pogodin joined his old friend [[Stepan Shevyrev]] in editing ''[[Moskvityanin]]'' (The Muscovite), a periodical which came to voice [[Slavophile]] opinions. In the course of the following fifteen years of editing, Pogodin and Shevyrev steadily slid towards the most reactionary form of Slavophilism. Their journal became embroiled in a controversy with the Westernizers, led by [[Alexander Herzen]], who deplored Pogodin's "rugged, unbroomed style, his rough manner of jotting down cropped notes and unchewed thoughts".
Pogodin's main focus during the last segment of his scholarly career was on fending off [[Nikolay Kostomarov|Kostomarov]]'s attacks against the [[Normanist theory]]. By that period, he championed the [[pan-Slavic]] idea of uniting [[Western Slavs]] under the aegis of the tsars and even visited [[Prague]] to discuss his plans with [[Pavel Jozef Šafárik]] and [[František Palacký]]. In the 1870s he was again pitted against a leading historian, this time [[Dmitry Ilovaisky]], who advocated an [[Iran]]ian origin of the earliest East Slavic rulers.
His grandson Mikhail Ivanovich Pogodin (1884–1969) was a museologist.

{{refimprove|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox Museum |name = The Museum of the City of Athens |image = Vouros Otto.jpg |imagesize = 250 |map_type = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 1973 |dissolved = |location = 5-7 Paparigopoulou Str., [[Athens]], [[Greece]] |type = City museum |visitors = |director = |curator = |publictransit = [[Athens Metro]] stations:
Panepistimio |website = }} '''Museum of the City of Athens''' Vouros - Eutaxias is a [[museum]] in [[Athens]], [[Greece]]. It houses a collection of a variety of Athens-related items collected by art collector Lambros Eutaxias (1905-1996). It includes antiquities, Byzantine art, sculptures, paintings, drawings, photographs and metal, glass and textile works. Also it includes furniture arranged in typical living rooms of the Athenian aristocracy of the 19th century. This building was the first royal palace of Greece under the reign of King [[Otto of Greece]].John Van der Kiste, Kings of the Hellenes: The Greek Kings 1863–1974 (Sutton Publishing, 1994). ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.athenscitymuseum.gr/ Official website] *[http://www.breathtakingathens.com/node/4711 City of Athens] *[http://www.athensinfoguide.com/wtsmuseums/muscityofathens.htm www.athensinfoguide.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080510144411/http://www.greece-museums.com/museum/115/ www.greece-museums.com] {{coord|37|58|43.85|N|23|43|53.5|E|display=title}} {{Museums in Athens}} [[Category:Museums in Athens]] [[Category:Royal residences in Greece]] [[Category:City museums]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Greece]] [[Category:Houses completed in 1831]] [[Category:Museums established in 1973]] [[Category:1973 establishments in Greece]] {{Greece-museum-stub}} {{Athens-struct-stub}}

The '''Number of Identified Specimens''' or '''Number of Individual Specimens'''<ref>{{Citation |last= Niven|first= L. |year= 2001 |title= The role of mammoths in Upper Palaeolithic economies of southern Germany|publisher= Institut für Ur- und Frühgeschichte und Archaeologie des Mittelalters|publication-place= Tübingen|url=http://www.cq.rm.cnr.it/elephants2001/pdf/323_327.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427110554/http://www.cq.rm.cnr.it/elephants2001/pdf/323_327.pdf |archivedate=27 April 2006}}</ref> ('''NISP'''), is used in [[archaeology]] and [[paleontology]] when counting [[bone]]s from a site. NISP counts each bone and fragment as one unit.
NISP can often be an overestimate of the actual number of individuals at the site, especially when preservation is good but bones are highly fragmented. Multiple fragments of the same bone lead to it being counted multiple times. However, too much fragmentation can lead to an inability to identify a bone as a particular type in the first place. At many sites with poor preservation the total NISP severely underestimates the total possible number of individuals that contributed to the assemblage. Some paleoindian sites, which often exhibit poor organic preservation, are a case in point. However, this and some other problems can be corrected analytically.
A more serious problem is the one of interdependence. There is generally no reliable way to determine if individually counted specimens originated from the same organism on the ancient landscape and are therefore interdependent. Since dependence is generally possible, NISP consistently overestimates, and to some unmeasurable extent, the actual number of individual animals represented in a recovered assemblage.
An alternative estimate to NISP, often done in concert, is [[minimum number of individuals]] (MNI). Both are influenced by fragmentation and limited preservation, but in different ways.<ref>Marshall, F. & Pilgram, T. (1993) NISP vs. MNI in Quantification of Body-Part Representation. ''American Antiquity'', 58(2), 261-269.</ref> NISP tends to overestimate the number of individuals under moderate fragmentation, but the overestimate lessens as fragmentation increases due to the inability to classify the bones. MNI tends to underestimate the actual number under medium fragmentation, and even more severely when bones are highly fragmented. Under hypothetically perfect preservation and no fragmentation, these estimates should be the same. MNI also suffers from the aggregation problem, in which different aggregations will generate at least two values, a MNI minimum and maximum, which are generally empirically indistinguishable. Both NISP and MNI are likely only ordinals scale measurements, which means at best they can only give an ordered series of taxonomic abundance, i.e. "Taxon A is more numerous than Taxon B."
NISP should not be used when calculating a sample size for inferential statistics, because it will inflate the statistical significance.<ref>Marshall & Pilgram (1993)</ref> Thus in these situations [[Minimum Number of Individuals|MNI]] should be used instead.

{{About|a southwest Nigerian fraternal organisation|the indigenous people of southeast Nigeria|Ogoni people}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
'''Ogboni''' (also known as '''Osugbo''' in [[Ijèbú]]) is a [[fraternal institution]] indigenous to the [[Yoruba language]]-speaking polities of [[Nigeria]], [[Republic of Bénin]] and [[Togo]], as well as among the [[Edo people]]. A similar group in [[Igbo language|Igbo]]-speaking areas is called [[Nze na Ozo]]. The society performs a range of political and religious functions, including exercising a profound influence on [[monarch]]s and serving as [[Supreme court|high court]]s of [[jurisprudence]] in [[capital offense]]s.
Its members are generally considered to constitute the [[nobility]] of the various [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] kingdoms of [[West Africa]].
==The Iwarefa== Each Ogboni lodge is led by a group of six principal officers that are collectively known as the ''Iwarefa'' ( lit. "The Six Wise Men"). These individuals are the most powerful figures in the [[polity]] that the lodge serves and are the inner council of advisors to its [[king]] or [[viceroy]]al [[chieftain]].
==Influence== Though versions of this fraternal group are found among the various types of [[Yoruba (people)|Yoruba]] states – from highly centralized [[Monarchy|kingdoms]] and [[empire]]s like [[Oyo Empire|Oyo]], to the independent towns and villages of the [[Ègbá]] and the [[Ekiti State|Èkiti]] – the Ogboni are recognizable for their veneration of the personified earth (Ilè or Oduduwa) and their emphasis on both gerontocratic authority and benevolent service to the community. While membership in the Ogboni generally signified a high level of power and prestige, the society held pre-eminent political authority among decentralized groups like the Ègbá, where they were intimately involved in the selection of rulers that served as little other than figureheads in practice. In contemporary [[Yorubaland]], Ogboni members still command great power and influence in the affairs of their societies, although this is largely due to the history of their respective [[chieftain]]cies and not to any official authority.
Ogboni lodges were one of the main commissioners of brass [[jewelry]] and sculpture in pre-colonial Yorubaland, using the metal's [[rust]]-resistant qualities as an apt [[metaphor]] for the [[Immortality|immortal]] functions and beliefs of Ogboni adepts. The most recognizable of these symbols was a pair of Ogboni initiates, one male and one female, attached by a chain and worn around the neck. The pair are thought to symbolize the attachment of the sexes in procreation and balanced society. Generally, one or both figures will hold a thumb in the grip of the opposite hand, demonstrating the paramount Ogboni [[handsign]] denoting initiation and membership.
==Legacy== A number of fraternities in Nigeria have incorporated references and insignia from the original Ogboni, including the Reformed Ogboni Fraternity, the Indigenous Ogboni, and various others. Many of these contemporary societies combine elements of Ogboni’s historical functions with superficially similar institutions like [[Freemasonry]] and the [[Rotary Club]].
Similar traditional institutions combining political, judicial, and sacred duties exist among the various ethnic nationalities of southern [[Nigeria]], including [[Nze na Ozo]] in [[Igbo people|Igbo]]-speaking southeast Nigeria and [[Ekpe|Ekpe/Ngbe/Ugbe]] in the [[Cross River (Nigeria)|Cross River]] region of southeastern Nigeria and southwestern [[Cameroon]]. Initiatory [[secret societies]] are a common feature of pre-colonial government across much of [[West Africa|West]] and [[Central Africa]].

{{unreferenced|date=January 2009}} [[Image:PavleIngorokva.jpg|thumb|Pavle Ingorokva]]
'''Pavle Ingorokva''' ([[Georgian alphabet|Georgian:]] პავლე ინგოროყვა) (January 1, 1893 in [[Poti]] – November 20, 1983 in [[Tbilisi]]) was a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] [[historian]], [[Philology|philologist]], and public benefactor.
He graduated from the [[Saint Petersburg State University|University of St. Petersburg]] (1916). In 1917 he was one of the founders of the [[Union of Georgian Writers]]. In 1917-1919 he was a member of the "National Council of Georgia". On May 26, 1918 Ingorokva signed the "Act of Independence of Georgia". In 1921 he protested the occupation of Georgia by the Bolshevist Russia, in 1921-1923 Ingorokva was a member of the group "Shavchokhianebi" ("Blackchokhians"). In 1924-1925, he was the [[Editor in chief|editor-in-chief]] of the Georgian scientific and literary Journal [[Kavkasioni]] ("The Caucasus"). The Journal was closed by the Bolshevik regime.
In 1925 Ingorokva founded the Publishing House "Kartuli Tsigni" ("The Georgian Book"). This Publishing House published works of [[Ilia Chavchavadze]] in the XI volumes (1926-1928) and works of other outstanding Georgian authors. In 1933 "Kartuli Tsigni" was closed.
In 1929-1940 Ingorokva was a Head of the Department of Manuscripts of the State Museum of Georgia (now the [[Georgian National Museum]]), in 1940-1950 a senior research fellow of the [[Institute of History]] ([[Tbilisi]]). In 1958 he was one of the founders of the Institute of Manuscripts (now the [[Georgian National Center of Manuscripts]]). He was also a member of the Commission on Study of ''[[The Knight in the Panther's Skin]]'' of the [[Georgian Academy of Sciences]] (GAS) (now [[Georgian National Academy of Sciences]]).
Pavle Ingorokva's main fields of the scientific activity were the history of the Georgian literature, history of Georgia, source studies of the history of Georgia, Rustavelology (Study of the works of the mediaeval Georgian writer [[Shota Rustaveli]]), history of Georgian script, etc. Some of his findings have proved extremely contentious and most western scholars dispute them, claiming his work is biased from an [[ethno-nationalistic]] perspective; this is especially in regard to his discussion of the [[ethnogenesis]] of the Georgians and [[Abkhaz people|Abkhaz]], and the age of the [[Georgian alphabet]]. A discussion of Ingoroqva’s work can be found in Bruno Coppieters, “In Defence of the Homeland: Intellectuals and the Georgian-Abkhazian Conflict” in Secession, History and the Social Sciences, ed. by Bruno Coppieters and Michel Huysseune, ('''VUB'''Press, 2002), p. 93-94.

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox Canal |name = Sankey Canal |image = 2004-10-09 Sankey Canal.jpg |image_caption = The Sankey Canal |former_names = |original_owner = Sankey Brook Navigation Co |engineer = Henry Berry |other_engineer = |date_act = 1755 |date_use = 1757 |date_completed = |date_closed = 1963 |date_restored = |len = |len_in = |original_boat_length = |original_boat_length_in = |len_note = |beam = |beam_in = |original_beam = |original_beam_in = |beam_note = |start_point = St Helens |original_start = |start_note = |end_point = Widnes |original_end = |end_note = |branch = |branch_of = |connects_to = [[River Mersey]] |locks = 3 |original_num_locks = |lock_note = |elev = |elev_note = |status = Partly restored |navigation_authority = }} {{Sankey Canal map}} The '''Sankey Canal''' in [[North West England]] connects [[St Helens, Merseyside|St Helens]] to the [[River Mersey]] at [[Spike Island (Cheshire)|Spike Island]].<ref>{{Coord|53.4458|-2.6448|region:GB_scale:10000}}</ref> When opened in 1757, it followed the valley of the Sankey Brook from where the brook joined the [[River Mersey]] past [[Warrington]] to [[Parr, St Helens|Parr]] at the north east of what became St Helens town centre.<ref>{{cite web|title=History, Opening of the canal|url=http://www.penninewaterways.co.uk/sankey/sa2.htm|accessdate=2013-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{Coord|53.3512|-2.7303|region:GB_scale:5000}}</ref> Extensions were constructed at the Mersey end to Fiddlers Ferry and then to Widnes, while at the northern end it was extended to [[Sutton, St Helens|Sutton]]. The canal was abandoned between 1931 and 1963 but has been the object of a restoration attempt since 1985 when the Sankey Canal Restoration Society was formed.
==History== The Sankey Canal was built principally to transport [[coal]] from [[Haydock Collieries]] and Parr to the growing chemical industries of Liverpool, although [[iron ore]] and corn were important cargoes. The industries rapidly expanded, and spread along the line of the canal to St Helens, [[Haydock]], [[Newton le Willows]] and Widnes, which were small villages until this period. The canal was an important factor in the industrial growth of the region.
The line of the canal was surveyed by [[Henry Berry]] and William Taylor, for which they charged £66. Berry, who had previously worked with [[Thomas Steers]], [[Liverpool]]’s first dock engineer, on the [[Newry Canal]] in [[Northern Ireland]], was Liverpool’s second dock engineer, but was appointed engineer for the navigation when the promoters convinced the Dock Trustees to release him for two days a week. It is not known whether Berry or the promoters presented the plans to parliament as an upgrade to the river navigation, despite building it as a true canal, but it is thought to be the only time a canal was authorised by parliament without anyone petitioning against it.<ref>{{harvnb |Skempton |2002 |p=54}}</ref>
The [[Act of Parliament]] authorising the construction of the navigation was passed on 20 March 1755, and was entitled ''An Act for making navigable the River or Brook called Sankey Brook, and Three several Branches thereof from the River Mersey below Sankey Bridges, up to Boardman's Stone Bridge on the South Branch, to Gerrard's Bridge on the Middle Branch, and to Penny Bridge on the North Branch, all in the county palatine of Lancaster.''<ref name=priestley558>{{harvnb |Priestley |1831|p=558}}</ref> The canal was open and carrying coal by 1757;<ref name=jane>{{harvnb |Cumberlidge |1998 |pp=186–187}}</ref> carriage of all goods was charged at a flat rate of 10d (ten ''old'' pence – £0.04) per [[long ton|ton]].<ref name=priestley558/>
As the title of the Act states, in addition to the mainline between the Mersey and Parr, three branches were built to nearby collieries: the South Branch to Boardman's Stone Bridge, Parr; the Middle Branch to Gerrard's Bridge; and the North Branch to Penny Bridge.
A second Act of Parliament was obtained on 8 April 1762, amending the earlier act, and was entitled ''An Act to amend and render more effectual, an Act made in the Twenty-eighth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, for making navigable Sankey Brook, in the county of Lancaster, and for the extending and improving the said Navigation''. This authorised the extension of the navigation to Fiddler's Ferry on the River Mersey, and to take an additional toll of two-pence per ton, making the rate one shilling (£0.05) per ton.<ref name=priestley559>{{harvnb |Priestley |1831|p=559}}</ref> The line of this extension was surveyed by John Eyes, who acted as principal witness to see the bill through parliament.<ref>{{harvnb |Skempton |2002 |p=220}}</ref>
An early trial of steam power took place<ref name=priestley559/> on 16 June 1797, when, according to the ''Billing's Liverpool Advertiser'', dated 26 June, John Smith's "vessel heavily laden with copper slag, passed along the Sankey Canal ... by the application of steam only ... it appears, that the vessel after a course of 10 miles [16 km], returned the same evening to St Helens whence it had set out". The boat was powered by a [[Newcomen steam engine|Newcomen engine]] working a paddle crankshaft through a beam and connecting rod.
To counter competition from the new railways, another extension was planned from Fiddler's Ferry across Cuerdley and [[Widnes]] Salt Marshes to Widnes Wharf, on the west bank of the River Mersey near Runcorn Gap, creating a second connection to the Mersey and another basin. This was authorised by a third Act of Parliament, granted on 29 May 1830, entitled ''An Act to consolidate and amend the Acts relating to the Sankey Brook Navigation, in the county of Lancaster; and to make a New Canal from the said Navigation at Fidler's Ferry, to communicate with the River Mersey at Widness Wharf, near West Bank, in the township of Widnes, in the said county,' repeals the former acts of the 28th George II. and 2nd George III. and incorporates the proprietors under the title of "The Company of Proprietors of the Sankey Brook Navigation."''<ref>{{harvnb |Priestley |1831|pp=559–560}}</ref> [[Francis Giles]] was appointed engineer for this extension, which opened in 1833. In 1825 Giles, who was a pupil of [[John Rennie the Elder|John Rennie]] and involved in many canal projects of the period, had proposed a link from the Sankey, via an aqueduct across the Mersey, to the Bridgewater Canal and the Mersey and Irwell Navigation, but this was never implemented.<ref>{{harvnb |Skempton |2002 |pp=251–254}}</ref>
[[File:Sankey viaduct.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Sankey Viaduct]]]]
The Sankey Canal was built for [[Mersey Flat]]s, the common sailing craft of the local rivers; they were used on the Mersey, [[River Irwell|Irwell]] and [[River Weaver|Weaver]] and along the Lancashire and [[North Wales]] coasts. To allow for the masts of the flats, [[swing bridges]] were constructed where roads crossed the canal. When the railways were built, they too had to cross in similar fashion. The exception was at [[Earlestown]], where [[George Stephenson]] erected the [[Sankey Viaduct]] for the [[Liverpool and Manchester Railway]], leaving {{convert|70|ft|m|sing=on}} headroom for the flats' sails. It is unclear how the flats' masts were accommodated at Great Sankey, where the Liverpool–Warrington–Manchester line built by the Cheshire Lines Committee in 1873 crosses the Sankey on a 12-arch viaduct less than twenty feet above the water level of the canal.
In 1877, it was reportedly the case that, due to the pollution of a local [[Leblanc process|Leblanc alkali works]], "The mud deposited in the Sankey Brook, near St Helens, has been found to contain ''no less than 2.26 percent of [[arsenic]]''...The water of the Sankey Brook is so acid that iron fittings cannot safely be used in the barges and lock gates."<ref name="Pollution-1877">{{harvnb|Higgins|1877|p=28}}</ref> Reportedly, by 1891, {{convert|500|acre|km2}} of nearby [[Widnes]] and [[Ditton, Cheshire|Ditton Marshes]] were buried under an average depth of {{convert|12|ft|m}} of toxic [[Leblanc process#Pollution issues|galligu]] from alkali operations near the Sankey Canal. The galligu detritus was estimated at 10 million tonnes in total weight.<ref>{{cite web|title=Contaminated Land: Galligu|url=http://www2.halton.gov.uk/content/environment/environmentalhealth/contaminatedland/galligu/?a=5441|accessdate=2009-05-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009223526/http://www2.halton.gov.uk/content/environment/environmentalhealth/contaminatedland/galligu?a=5441|archivedate=9 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It is unknown what level of pollution exists in said brook as of 2009, though [[Leblanc process#Pollution issues|galligu]], [[alkali|soap]] and [[soda ash|ash]] waste have been reported in the vicinity. In the present, discoveries of arsenic, lead and mercury have been found as common contaminants in the soil of local gardens.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arsenic, lead and mercury is in gardens|url=http://archive.thisischeshire.co.uk/2004/11/18/140109.html|publisher=This Is Cheshire|date=2004-11-18|accessdate=2009-05-07}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On top of this, St Michael’s Golf Course, a municipal golf course in nearby Widnes built atop "30 hectares of land from old chemical waste tips", was forced to close due to high levels of [[arsenic]] found in the soil, that created a public hazard.<ref>{{cite web|title=Contaminated Land: St Michael's Golf Course|url=http://www2.halton.gov.uk/content/environment/environmentalhealth/contaminatedland/stmichealsgolfcourse/?a=5441|accessdate=2009-05-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009223645/http://www2.halton.gov.uk/content/environment/environmentalhealth/contaminatedland/stmichealsgolfcourse?a=5441|archivedate=9 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Structures==
A staircase [[Canal lock|lock]] was built on the Sankey Canal and a second staircase was built later when the Ravenhead Branch was constructed in 1775. They are known respectively as the Old Double Lock and the New Double Lock. The latter was restored by St Helens Borough Council<ref name=jane2009>{{harvnb |Cumberlidge |2009 |pp=262–263}}</ref> in 1992, although it has no navigable waterway either above or below it.
==Operation==
Built primarily to take coal from [[Haydock]] and [[Parr, St Helens|Parr]] down to the Mersey and so on to the saltfields of Cheshire and Liverpool, the final traffic on the Sankey Canal was very different, and in the opposite direction, consisting of raw sugar for the Sankey Sugar Works at Earlestown, [[Newton-le-Willows]], from Liverpool. [[File:St Helen's Canal & Railway Company.JPG|thumb|right|The seal of St Helens Canal and Railway Company]] The canal’s immediate commercial success, followed soon after by that of the [[Bridgewater Canal]], led to a mania of canal building, and for further extension schemes to be proposed for the Sankey Canal. Francis Giles' proposal to link the canal to the Bridgwater Canal was not implemented, and neither was a plan to link the canal to the [[Leeds and Liverpool Canal]] near [[Leigh (Greater Manchester)|Leigh]], to the North-East. Apart from the early extension to Fiddlers Ferry, which provided better access to the River Mersey, and the 1775 extension to St Helens, the only major change came with the extension to Widnes in the 1830s.
In 1845 the [[St Helens and Runcorn Gap Railway|St Helens and Runcorn Gap Railway Company]] and the then more prosperous Canal Company merged to form the St Helens Canal and Railway Company.<ref name=jane/> Its occasionally used name is the St Helens Canal.
==Decline== The ending of the sugar traffic in 1959 led to the closure of the canal in 1963.<ref name=jane/> North of the sugar works, closure had taken place in 1931,<ref name=jane/> and fixed bridges quickly replaced the old wooden swing bridges. The canal, however, remains largely in water right up into the centre of St Helens, although its terminus had been truncated in 1898, when Canal Street was built over it.
==Restoration== Restoration of the canal began in 1980, when work began on the section between Bewsey and Liverpool Road, Great Sankey, funded by a Derelict Land Grant.<ref>{{harvnb |Squires |2008 |p=111}}</ref> Most of the canal is still in water and much has been restored to navigable standard, with short sections at Fiddlers Ferry, Warrington and Spike Island, Widnes having locks into the Mersey which have allowed craft access to the canal for mooring since the locks were restored in the 1980s.<ref name=jane2009/> However, fixed bridges which replaced the original wooden swing bridges and other obstructions isolate the sections from one another. The route of the canal passes through the [[Sankey Valley Park]] and the towpath from Sankey Bridges to Widnes now forms part of the [[Trans Pennine Trail]].<ref>[http://www.transpenninetrail.org.uk/template.asp?ID=482&parentID=478 Places on the Trail West] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120913210516/http://www.transpenninetrail.org.uk/template.asp?ID=482&parentID=478 |date=13 September 2012 }}</ref>
There are plans to restore the canal, and to extend it to join the main canal system via the [[Leeds and Liverpool Canal]]. The total cost of this would be in excess of £100m and it is therefore a long-term project. There are, however, plans to dig out an infilled section in the centre of St Helens as part of the town's Eastside development. A feasibility study for this work was funded by a grant from the Single Regeneration Budget Fund, while at the other end of the canal, the Widnes Waterfront plan, published by Halton Council,<ref>{{harvnb |Squires |2008 |pp=157–158}}</ref> and the proposed new Mersey crossing between Widnes and Runcorn are expected to lead to further restoration at Widnes.
The section of the Sankey Canal running from St Helens to [[Newton le Willows]] is expected to be the most difficult to restore, and is likely to involve the laying of a complete new canal bed. Work on the new canal was due to begin in 2009.{{update inline|date=March 2012}}

[[File:Mosque and Bait Siyadi, Muharraq, Bahrain.jpg|thumb|The Siyadi [[mosque]] and the Siyadi house behind it.]] '''Siyadi House''', also known as Bayt Siyadi (Arabic: بيت سيادي) is a [[historic building]] in [[Muharraq]] City, [[Kingdom of Bahrain]]. It is part of a larger complex of buildings constructed for the pearl [[merchant]] Abdullah bin Isa Siyadi, which further includes a [[Bahrain_pearling_trail#Description|mosque]] and a [[majlis]]. While the Siyadi House was built under Ahmad bin Jassim Siyadi, the construction of the Siyadi Majlis was initiated by Ahmad bin Jassim Siyadi and the Siyadi Mosque was a shared initiative of Isa and Jassim bin Ahmad Siyadi.<ref>Ministry of Culture and Information: ''Pearling, Testimony of an island economy'', 2010, p. 156</ref> It is also a part of the [[Bahrain pearling trail]], the second [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] in the country.
==History== The Siyadi family arrived to Bahrain in the early 19th century and settled close to the rulers’ houses in the Sh. Abdallah neighbourhood. The family's wealth originated from their involvement in the pearl trade, which blossomed in Muharraq in the 19th century.<ref>Ministry of Culture and Information: ''Pearling, Testimony of an island economy'', 2010, p. 158</ref>
==Architecture== The oldest part of the complex is Siyadi Mosque, which Isa and Jassim bin Yousif Siyadi donated to the Muharraq community in 1865. The original building was later revised and, according to Yarwood, the preserved structure dates to 1910.<ref>John Yarwood: ''Al-Muharraq: Architectural Heritage of a Bahraini City'', 2005</ref> the Siyadi Mosque is the oldest preserved mosque in Muharraq and is still used for [[daily prayers]].
Siyadi Majlis was constructed in two phases; the first phase initiated by Jassim bin Yousif Siyadi in 1850, which covered the ground floor and the upper-storey rooms constructed during the second phase in 1921. The largest part of the complex, Siyadi House is still used as a [[private residence]] and is inhabited by Abdallah bin Hassan Siyadi, the grandson of the builder Abdallah bin Isa Siyadi. It is not open to accessible to public and cannot be visited. The 450 square meters residence was the last construction and is dated to 1931.
The three buildings illustrate elaborate decorations of the late [[Pearl hunting|pearling]] era of Bahrain, in particular Siyadi Majlis has an inside room worth visiting.<ref>John Falagan: ''We're all men here'', 2007, p. 294</ref> At present the Siyadi Majlis is under the responsibility of the [[Culture minister|Ministry of Culture, Bahrain]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{about|the town on the island of Lanzarote|the municipality|Teguise (municipality)}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Teguise | native_name = | other_name = | settlement_type = Town | translit_lang1_type = Spanish | image_skyline = Teguise 2009 130.JPG | image_caption = Plaza Mayor | image_flag = | image_shield = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = Spain Canary Islands | pushpin_map_caption = Location in the [[Canary Islands]] | coordinates = {{coord|29|3|36|N|13|33|37|W|region:ES|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{flag|Spain}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Autonomous Community]] | subdivision_name1 = {{flag|Canary Islands}} | subdivision_type2 = [[Provinces of Spain|Province]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Province of Las Palmas|Las Palmas]] | subdivision_type3 = [[Island]] | subdivision_name3 = [[Lanzarote]] | subdivision_type4 = [[Municipality]] | subdivision_name4 = [[Teguise (municipality)|Teguise]] | established_title = | established_date = | leader_party = | leader_title = | leader_name = | area_total_km2 = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = | population_footnotes = | population_total = 1,732 | population_as_of = 2011 | population_density_km2 = auto | timezone1 = [[Central European Time|CET]] | utc_offset1 = +0 | timezone1_DST = CEST (GMT +1) | utc_offset1_DST = +1 | postal_code_type = [[Postal code]] | postal_code = 35530 | area_code = [[+34]] (Spain) + 928 (Las Palmas) | website = }} '''Teguise''' ({{IPA-es|teˈɣise|pron}}), also known in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as ''La Villa de Teguise'', is a village in the municipality of [[Teguise (municipality)|Teguise]] in the north-central part of the island of [[Lanzarote]] in [[Las Palmas (province)|Las Palmas province]] in the [[Canary Islands]]. The town's population was 1,732 in the 2011 census.<ref>[http://www.ine.es/nomen2/index.do?accion=busquedaAvanzada&entidad_amb=no&codProv=35&codMuni=24&codEC=0&codES=17&codNUC=0&L=0 INE 2011 census. La Villa de Teguise] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213041416/http://www.ine.es/nomen2/index.do?accion=busquedaAvanzada&entidad_amb=no&codProv=35&codMuni=24&codEC=0&codES=17&codNUC=0&L=0 |date=2013-12-13 }}</ref>
The town is the capital of the [[Municipalities of Spain|municipality]] of [[Teguise (municipality)|Teguise]].
A market is held in the town on Sunday mornings, and has become a popular tourist attraction.<ref>[http://www.teguise.com/mercadillo-in.html www.teguise.com - Sunday Market]</ref>
==History== The town was founded in 1414. Teguise served as the capital of the [[Kingdom of the Canary Islands]] from 1425 to 1448 and as capital of the island until the capital moved to [[Arrecife]] in 1852. <gallery mode=packed heights=150> File:Castell de Santa Barbara.jpg|Santa Bárbara Castle File:Teguise Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe.jpg|Church Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe </gallery>

:''For the group of paintings known by this title, see [[The Allegory of Love (Veronese)]].'' [[File:TheAllegoryOfLove.jpg|thumb|First edition (publ. [[Clarendon Press]])]] '''''The Allegory of Love: A Study in Medieval Tradition''''' ([[1936 in literature|1936]]), by [[C. S. Lewis]] ({{ISBN|0192812203}}), is an exploration of the [[Allegory|allegorical]] treatment of love in the [[Middle Ages]] and the [[Renaissance]], which was released on May 21, 1936.
In the first chapter, Lewis traces the development of the idea of [[courtly love]] from the Provençal [[troubadour]]s to its full development in the works of [[Chrétien de Troyes]]. It is here that he sets forth a famous characterization of "the peculiar form which it [courtly love] first took; the four marks of Humility, Courtesy, Adultery, and the Religion of Love"—the last two of which "marks" have, in particular, been the subject of a good deal of controversy among later scholars. In the second chapter, Lewis discusses the medieval evolution of the allegorical tradition in such writers as [[Bernard Silvestris]] and [[Alain de Lille]].
The remaining chapters, drawing on the points made in the first two, examine the use of allegory in the depiction of love in a selection of poetic works, beginning with the ''[[Roman de la Rose]]''. The focus, however, is on English works: the poems of [[Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer]], [[John Gower|Gower's]] ''[[Confessio Amantis]]'' and [[Thomas Usk|Usk's]] ''Testament of Love'', the works of Chaucer's epigones, and [[Edmund Spenser|Spenser's]] ''[[The Faerie Queene|Faerie Queene]]''.
The book is ornamented with quotations from poems in many languages, including [[Classical Latin|Classical]] and [[Medieval Latin]], [[Middle English]], and [[Old French]]. The piquant English translations of many of these are Lewis's own work.
==External links== * [http://www.lewisiana.nl/allegsum Detailed summary of ''The Allegory of Love'']

{{italic title}} {{Context|date=November 2009}} In a diagram from the book ''The Automated Society'',<ref> Bloomfield, Masse, ''The Automated Society'', Masefield Books, 1995.</ref> Bloomfield defines the history of humanity beginning over two million years ago and ending over a hundred thousand years in the future. The diagram is base on biological [[punctuated equilibrium]] and a parallel [[cultural evolution]]. The predictions of the [[future]] follow what has happened in the past.
The diagram of [[history]] shows humanity having long periods of stability interrupted with short periods of transition. Humanity is currently experiencing one of those short periods of transition, from a stable agricultural period going through a transitional [[industrial society]] leading to a stable automated period. [[Productivity]] is the key to the transition; when it is impossible to increase productivity, humanity will have arrived at the automated society.
Before humanity enters the automated society, we will suffer from two near term trends. One trend is the relentlessly increasing number of human beings. The second is the relentlessly decreasing number of jobs. Jobs will be eliminated by substituting men with machines. An example of this is agriculture where once in the peasant society there were ninety percent of the people working as farmers. With the introduction of tractors, only three percent of Americans work on the farm.
Once the problems of the lack of jobs, increased [[pollution]] and fewer natural resources are solved and the food factory put in operation, there should be a reconciliation of man to [[automation]]. In the automated society, men will live in affluence along with a total control of [[population]]. The one place where man will have an unlimited future will be in space. [[Space]] can provide for an unlimited increase in population and potentially the introduction of new human biological species.
== See also == * [[Accelerating change]] * [[Automation]] * [[Productivity]] * [[Punctuated equilibrium]] * [[Sociocultural Evolution]] * ''[[Mankind in Transition]]''
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://massebloomfield.com/books/the-automated-society/ The Automated Society by Masse Bloomfield]

[[File:Ronald Reagan TV Address 1981.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=4|right|alt=President Reagan and his line chart titled "Your taxes" which shows rising taxes.|[[Ronald Reagan]] gives a televised address from the [[Oval Office]], outlining his plan for tax reductions in July 1981 (excerpt)]] This '''timeline of modern American conservatism''' lists important events, developments, and occurrences which have significantly affected [[conservatism in the United States]]. With the decline of the conservative wing of the Democratic Party after 1960, the movement is most closely associated with the [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] (GOP). [[Fiscal conservatism|Economic conservatives]] favor less government regulation, lower taxes, and weaker labor unions, while [[Social conservatism in the United States|social conservatives]] focus on moral issues and neoconservatives focus on democracy worldwide. Conservatives generally distrust the United Nations (UN) and Europe and, apart from the [[Libertarian Republican|libertarian wing]], favor a strong military and give enthusiastic support to Israel.<ref>Michael T. Thomas (2007). ''American policy toward Israel: the power and limits of beliefs.'' Routledge. pp. 42–43.</ref>
Although conservatism has much older roots in American history, the modern movement began to gel in the mid–1930s when intellectuals and politicians collaborated with businessmen to oppose the liberalism of the [[New Deal]], led by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] (FDR), newly energized [[Labor unions in the United States|labor unions]], and big city Democratic machines. After World War II that coalition gained strength from new philosophers and writers who developed an intellectual rationale for conservatism.<ref>Patrick Allitt (2009). ''The Conservatives: Ideas and Personalities Throughout American History.'' Yale University Press. ch 1–6 covers the story down to 1945.</ref>
Richard Nixon's victory in the 1968 presidential election is often considered a realigning election in American politics. From 1932 to 1968, the Democratic Party was obviously the majority party. During that time period, the Democrats had won seven out of nine presidential elections, and their agenda gravely affected that undertaken by the Republican Eisenhower administration. The election of 1968 reversed the situation completely. The Vietnam war split the Democratic Party. White ethnics in the North and white Southerners felt the national Democratic Party had deserted them. The white South has voted Republican at the presidential level since the mid-1960s, and at the state and local level since the 1990s.
In the 1980s President [[Ronald Reagan]] solidified conservative Republican strength with [[tax cuts]], greatly increased [[Military budget of the United States|defense spending]], [[deregulation]], a policy of [[Reagan Doctrine|rolling back communism]] (rather than just containing it), a greatly strengthened military, and appeals to [[family values]] and conservative Judeo-Christian morality. His impact has led historians to call the 1980s the "[[Reagan Era]]".<ref>Sean Wilentz ''The Age of Reagan: A History, 1974–2008.'' (2009); John Ehrman ''The Eighties: America in the Age of Reagan.'' (2008) pp. 3–8.</ref> The Reagan model remains the conservative standard for social, economic and foreign policy issues. In recent years social issues such as abortion, gun control, and [[Same-sex marriage|gay marriage]] have become important. Since 2009 the [[Tea Party Movement]] has energized conservatives at the local level against the policies made by the [[presidency of Barack Obama]], leading to a Republican landslide in 2010 and again in 2014, eventually culminating in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|election of Republican Donald Trump as president in 2016]].
==Chronology of events== {{main|Conservatism in the United States|History of the United States Republican Party}}
===1930s=== As the nation plunges into its [[Great Depression in the United States|deepest depression ever]], Republicans and conservatives fall into disfavor in 1930, 1932, and 1934, losing more and more of their seats. Liberals (mostly Democrats with a few Republicans and independents) come to power with the [[United States presidential election, 1932|landslide 1932 election]] of liberal Democrat Franklin D. Roosevelt. In his first 100 days Roosevelt pushes through a series of dramatic economic programs known as the [[New Deal]].<ref>Anthony J. Badger (2009). ''FDR: the first hundred days''. Hilland Wang. pp. 3–22, 74.</ref>
The major metropolitan newspapers generally opposed the New Deal, as typified by [[William Randolph Hearst]] and his chain (Hearst had supported FDR in 1932 but parted ways in 1934.)<ref>{{cite book|author=Graham J. White|title=FDR and the Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q2_HXgc4u_4C&pg=PA51|year=1979|publisher=University of Chicago Press|pages=51–52|isbn=978-0226895123}}</ref> [[Robert R. McCormick]], owner of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', compared the New Deal to communism. He was also an [[America First Committee|America First]] [[isolationist]] who strongly opposed entering World War II to rescue the [[British Empire]]. McCormick also railed against the [[League of Nations]], the [[World Court]], socialism and communism.<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard Norton Smith|title=The Colonel: The Life and Legend of Robert R. McCormick, 1880–1955|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tIW6XTGsOAC&pg=PA349|year= 2003|publisher=Northwestern University Press|page=349|isbn=978-0810120396}}</ref>
;1934 * Opposition to New Deal policies first takes shape as the [[American Liberty League]]. Led by conservative Democrats such as [[Al Smith]], it fades after [[United States presidential election, 1936|Roosevelt's 1936 landslide]] and disbands in 1940.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Rudolph Frederick | year = 1950 | title = The American Liberty League, 1934–1940 | journal = American Historical Review | volume = 56 | issue = 1| pages = 19–33 | jstor=1840619}}</ref><ref>George Wolfskill (1962). ''The Revolt of the Conservatives: A History of the American Liberty League, 1934–1940.'' Houghton Mifflin. p. 249.</ref> Businessmen begin organizing their opposition especially to labor unions.<ref>{{cite book|author=Kim Phillips-Fein|title=Invisible Hands: The Businessmen's Crusade Against the New Deal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g0tCwOhyl7MC&pg=PA15|year=2010|publisher=W. W. Norton|page=15|isbn=978-0393337662}}</ref> ;1935 * Former President [[Herbert Hoover]] develops his critique of New Deal liberalism based on the values of liberty, limited government, and constitutionalism.<ref>Gordon Lloyd and David Davenport, ''The New Deal and Modern American Conservatism: A Defining Rivalry'' (2013) [https://www.amazon.com/Deal-Modern-American-Conservatism-ebook/dp/B00EXC1EGA/ excerpt and text search]</ref> ;1936 [[File:Oliver twist.gif|210px|thumb|alt=Cartoon of a greedy FDR and diminutive Congress.|1937 cartoon by Joseph L. Parrish in the ''Chicago Tribunes'' warning FDR's executive branch reorganization plan is a power grab.]] * President Roosevelt calls his opponents "conservatives" as a term of abuse, they reply that they are "true liberals".<ref>{{cite book|author=Brendon O'Connor|title=A Political History of the American Welfare System: When Ideas Have Consequences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GOfdvp_GQ34C&pg=PA38|year=2004|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=38|isbn=978-0742526686}}</ref> * Most publishers favor Republican moderate [[Alf Landon]] for president. In the nation's 15 largest cities the newspapers that editorially endorsed Landon represented 70% of the circulation, while Roosevelt won 69% of the actual voters.<ref>Charles W. Smith Jr. (1939). ''Public Opinion in a Democracy.'' Prentice-Hall. pp. 85–86.</ref> * FDR [[United States presidential election, 1936|carries 46 of the 48 states]] and liberals gain in both the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1936|House]] and the [[United States Senate elections, 1936|Senate]], thanks to newly energized labor unions, city machines, and the WPA.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sternsher | first1 = Bernard | year = 1984 | title = The New Deal Party System: A Reappraisal | journal = Journal of Interdisciplinary History | volume = 15 | issue = 1| pages = 53–81 | jstor=203594 | doi = 10.2307/203594}}</ref> Since 1928 the GOP has lost 178 House seats, 40 Senate seats, and 19 governorships; it retains a mere 89 seats in the House and 16 in the Senate.<ref>{{cite book|author=Michael Kazin, eta al, eds.|title=The Concise Princeton Encyclopedia of American Political History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7hScNkRpePoC&pg=PA203|year=2011|publisher=Princeton University Press|page=203|isbn=978-0691152073}}</ref> ;1937 * Roosevelt's plan to [[Judicial Procedures Reform Bill of 1937|pack the Supreme Court]] alienates conservative Democrats; most newspapers which supported FDR in 1936 oppose the plan, with many warning it was a prelude to dictatorship.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jeff Shesol|title=Supreme Power: Franklin Roosevelt Vs. The Supreme Court|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PtBJOuXmGf8C&pg=PA299|year=2011|publisher=W. W. Norton|pages=299, 301–03|isbn=978-0393338812}}</ref> * Conservative Republicans (nearly all from the North) and conservative Democrats (most from the South), form the [[Conservative Coalition]] and block most new liberal proposals until the 1960s.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Patterson | first1 = James T. | year = 1966 | title = A Conservative Coalition Forms in Congress, 1933–1939 | journal = Journal of American History | volume = 52 | issue = 4| pages = 757–72 | jstor=1894345 | doi = 10.2307/1894345}}</ref> * The [[Conservative Manifesto]] (originally titled "An Address to the People of the United States") rallies the opposition to Roosevelt. It is drafted by Senators [[Josiah Bailey]] (D-NC) and [[Arthur H. Vandenberg]] (R-MI).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = John Robert | first1 = Moore | year = 1965 | title = Senator Josiah W. Bailey and the "Conservative Manifesto" of 1937 | journal = Journal of Southern History | volume = 31 | issue = 1| pages = 21–39 | jstor=2205008 | doi = 10.2307/2205008}}</ref> * The liberal [[American Federation of Labor]] (AFL) and more leftist [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] (CIO) labor federations are both growing and both support FDR. Their bitter feud over jurisdiction, however, produces numerous strikes, angers public opinion and weakens their political power.<ref>Walter Galenson (1960). ''The CIO challenge to the AFL.'' Harvard University Press. p. 542.</ref> ;1938 * Opponents of conservatism weaken sharply. FDR's allies in the AFL and CIO battle each other; his court-packing plan is rejected; his attempt to purge the conservatives from the Democratic Party fails and strengthens them; the sharp [[recession of 1937–1938]] discredits his argument that New Deal policies would lead to full recovery.<ref>William E. Leuchtenburg (1963). ''Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal: 1932–1940.'' HarperCollins. pp. 231–74.</ref> * The Republicans make major gains in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1938|House]] and [[United States Senate elections, 1938|Senate]] in the 1938 elections.<ref>Milton Plesur, "The Republican Congressional Comeback of 1938," ''Review of Politics,'' Oct 1962, Vol. 24 Issue 4, pp. 525–62 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1405361 in JSTOR]</ref> * [[Leo Strauss]] (1899–1973), a refugee from Nazi Germany, teaches political philosophy at the [[New School for Social Research]] in New York (1938–49) and the University of Chicago (1949–1958). He was not an activist but his ideas have been influential.<ref>John P. East, "Leo Strauss and American Conservatism," [http://www.mmisi.org/ma/21_01/east.pdf ''Modern Age,'' (1977) 21:1 pp. 2–19 online]</ref> ;1939 [[File:RobertATaft.jpg|thumb|140px|alt=photograph of|Robert A. Taft]] * As Republican senator from Ohio (1939–53), [[Robert A. Taft]] leads the conservative opposition to liberal policies (apart from public housing and aid to education, which he supported). Taft opposed most of the New Deal, entry into World War II, NATO, and sending troops to the [[Korean War]]. He was not so much an "isolationist" as a staunch opponent of the ever-expanding powers of the White House. The growth of this power, Taft feared, would lead to dictatorship or at least spoil American democracy, [[republicanism in the United States|republicanism]] and civil virtue.<ref>Geoffrey Matthews, "Robert A. Taft, the Constitution and American Foreign Policy, 1939–53," ''Journal of Contemporary History,'' July 1982, Vol. 17 Issue 3, pp. 507–22</ref>
===1940s=== ;1943 * Medical missionary [[Walter Judd (politician)|Walter Judd]] (1898–1994) enters Congress (1943–63) and defines the conservative position on China as all-out support for the Nationalists under [[Chiang Kai-shek]] and opposition to the Communists under Mao. Judd redoubled his support after the Nationalists in 1949 fled to Formosa (Taiwan).<ref>Lee Edwards (1990). ''Missionary for Freedom: The Life and Times of Walter Judd.'' Paragon House. p. 210.</ref> * The [[American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research|American Enterprise Institute]] (AEI) is founded in Washington "to defend the principles and improve the institutions of American freedom and democratic capitalism—limited government, private enterprise, individual liberty and responsibility, vigilant and effective defense and foreign policies, political accountability, and open debate."<ref>Murray L. Weidenbaum (2009). ''The competition of ideas: the world of the Washington think tanks.'' Transaction Publishers. p. 23.</ref> ;1944 [[File:80 us house changes.png|thumb|alt=map shows GOP landslide in 1946|Party change of House seats in the 1946 GOP landslide]] * March: [[Friedrich Hayek]], an Austrian-born British economist, publishes ''[[The Road to Serfdom]]'', which is widely read in America and Britain. He warns that well-intentioned government intervention in the economy is a slippery slope that will lead to tight government controls over people's lives, just as medieval serfdom had done.<ref>F. A. Hayek (1944; 2nd ed. 2010). ''The Road to Serfdom.'' University of Chicago Press. 2nd ed. by Bruce Caldwell with prepublication reports on Hayek's manuscript, and forewords to earlier editions by [[John Chamberlain (journalist)|John Chamberlain]], Milton Friedman, and Hayek himself.</ref> * The weekly magazine ''[[Human Events]]'' is founded by [[Frank Hanighen]] and [[Felix Morley]] with a significant contribution from ex-New Dealer [[Henry Regnery]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/us/henry-regnery-84-ground-breaking-conservative-publisher.html |title=Henry Regnery, 84, Ground-Breaking Conservative Publisher |author=Robert McG. Thomas, Jr. |date=June 23, 1996 |work=New York Times |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/nrd/article/?q=ZTQ2MjE1MTYzYjQ3Mjk0MWU5MTE4YmQzMDkyMjE2NzM= |title=Turning the Tide |author=Richard V. Allen |date=June 2, 2008 |work=National Review Online |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref> Ronald Reagan later says that the magazine "helped me stop being a liberal Democrat."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=41609 |title=Reagan's Newspaper |author=Lee Edwards |date=February 5, 2011 |work=Human Events |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref> ; 1945 * [[Ludwig von Mises]] (1881–1973), having fled the Nazis, becomes professor of economics at New York University (1945–1969) where he disseminates [[Austrian School]] libertarianism.<ref>Israel M. Kirzner (2001). ''Ludwig von Mises: the man and his economics.'' ISI Books. p. 25.</ref> ;1946 * [[Milton Friedman]] (1912–2006) is appointed professor of economics at the University of Chicago.<ref>He retired in 1977 and moved to the [[Hoover Institution]] at Stanford. Milton and Rose Friedman (1999). ''Two Lucky People: Memoirs.'' University of Chicago Press. p. 559.</ref> Previously a [[Keynesian]], Friedman moves right under the influence of his close friend [[George Stigler]] (1911–1991). He founds the market-oriented [[Chicago School of Economics]] which reshapes conservative economic theory. Stigler opposes regulation of industry as counterproductive; Friedman undermines Keynesian macroeconomics.<ref>[[Alan O. Ebenstein]] (2009). ''Milton Friedman: A Biography'' Palgrave Macmillan. p. 259.</ref> Friedman wins the Nobel Prize in 1976 and Stigler in 1982. * November 5: Republicans score landslide victories in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1946|House]] and [[United States Senate elections, 1946|Senate]] in off-year elections and set about enacting a conservative agenda in the [[80th Congress]].<ref>Susan M. Hartmann (1971). ''Truman and the 80th Congress.'' University of Missouri Press. p. 7.</ref> [[File:Is this tomorrow.jpg|thumb|140px|alt=Cartoon book warning of Communist aggression|Warning against communism, 1947]] ;1947 * June: Congress passes the [[Taft-Hartley Act]], designed by conservatives to create what they consider a proper balance between the rights of management and the rights of labor. Unions call it a slave labor law; Truman vetoes it and both houses override the veto.<ref>James T. Patterson (1972). ''Mr. Republican: a biography of Robert A. Taft.'' Houghton Mifflin Company. pp. 352–68.</ref> ;1948 * Deep South Democrats led by [[Strom Thurmond]] split from the National Democratic Party to form the pro-[[Racial segregation|segregation]] [[States' Rights Democratic Party]] or Dixiecrat party. They are protesting support for civil rights legislation in the party platform and make Thurmond their nominee for president in the [[United States presidential election, 1948|1948 election]]. Nearly all return to the Democratic party in 1949.<ref>Kari A. Frederickson (2000). ''The Dixiecrat Revolt and the End of the Solid South, 1932–1968.'' The University of North Carolina Press. passim.</ref> * Scholar [[Richard M. Weaver]] publishes ''[[Ideas Have Consequences]]'', which influences intellectuals to question sophistic interpretations of literature.<ref>Fred D. Young (1995). ''Richard M. Weaver, 1910–1963: a life of the mind.'' University of Missouri. p. 9.</ref> * June: Liberal Republican Thomas Dewey again wins the [[1948 Republican National Convention|Republican nomination]], to the frustration of conservatives.<ref>Michael Bowen (2011). ''The Roots of Modern Conservatism: Dewey, Taft, and the Battle for the Soul of the Republican Party.'' The University of North Carolina Press. p. 66.</ref> * November: Pundits are astonished when Dewey loses to incumbent Democrat [[Harry S. Truman]] in the [[United States presidential election, 1948|presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,853326,00.html | work=Time | title=The Nation: Independence Day | date=1948-11-08 | accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>
===1950s=== After the war, businessmen opposed to New Deal liberalism read Hayek, fight labor unions, and fund politicized think tanks such as [[American Enterprise Institute]] (founded 1943). They promote statewide [[Right-to-work law|right-to-work]] campaigns.<ref>Kim Phillips-Fein (2009). ''Invisible Hands: The Businessmen's Crusade Against the New Deal.'' W. W. Norton & Company. ch 2.</ref> ;1950 * The intellectual reputation of conservatism reaches a low ebb; [[Lionel Trilling]] observes that "liberalism is not only the dominant but even the sole intellectual tradition" and dismisses conservatism as a series of "irritable mental gestures which seek to resemble ideas."<ref>{{cite book|author=Russell Kirk|title=The Conservative Mind: From Burke to Eliot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mGBn2fOdp7gC&pg=PA476|year= 2001|publisher=Regnery|page=476|isbn=978-0895261717}}</ref> * February: Republican Senator [[Joseph McCarthy]] gives a speech saying, "While I cannot take the time to name all the men in the State Department who have been named as members of the Communist Party and members of a spy ring, I have here in my hand a list of 205."
